reviewText:
Child of Light is a turn-based roleplaying game with a very distinctive pseudo-storybook graphical style, written entirely in rhyme. Many of its mechanics are reminiscent of Final Fantasy X – including some painful dialogue.

Gameplay

The game consists of two portions: environmental navigation and battle.
Environmental navigation is actually a bit tiresome; at the start of the game, the player can only walk and jump, but very soon they gain the ability to fly around the 2D environment, eliminating all of the platforming elements in the game very early. This has a somewhat negative influence on gameplay speed, the player must explore an environment from top to bottom to find all the items and secrets, greatly increasing the amount of space which needs to be explored. In parts, it works decently well, but frequently it is tiresome, and only a few environments full of puzzles and traps are even remotely interesting to navigate.
There are no random encounters in the game; rather, monsters appear and wander around on the screen, and will attempt to pursue the player if they see them. The player will be “ambushed” if the monster runs into them while their back is turned, and will ambush the monster in turn if they manage to run into the monster’s back. This means that most of the time, the player will ambush the monsters, as not only is navigation simple, but the player controls a small ball of light which can be used to temporarily stun the monsters, in addition to healing the player between combats and activating some switches and puzzles
The game’s combat is actually reasonably sophisticated. The player controls two characters in combat, and faces off with up to three enemies at a time. It is somewhat reminiscent of Final Fantasy X in many respects; the player can switch out their characters at any time during combat, including replacing KOed characters with another character, and different attacks have different speeds. However, unlike Final Fantasy X, there are two different speeds which matter: the base speed of the character, and the speed at which the character acts.
There are two portions of a gauge at the bottom of the screen; the first portion represents the time spent between turns, while the second, smaller section represents the time spent charging up to attack or perform some other action. Each action has its own speed through the second portion of this, and if someone is attacked while they are charging an action, their action is interrupted and their turn is reset into some random (or semi-random) portion of the between-turns section of the gauge. As such, the player can interrupt enemy attacks, or the enemies can interrupt player attacks. There are some means of protecting yourself from such things, and some monsters will automatically counterattack against certain types of attacks (physical or magical) or against attacks made while they’re charging their actions.
The characters are actually quite varied, with each character having their own skill-set which is unlocked via a character-specific skill tree. Each character has their own set of abilities, and there are two characters who are primarily magic users, a warrior who can force enemies to attack him, a character who focuses entirely on speeding up or slowing down allies and enemies, a couple of physical attack characters, and some support characters. Gauge manipulation, interrupting enemy attacks, exploiting enemy elemental vulnerabilities, and applying the right status ailments while keeping your own party healthy are all important. The ball of light you control while navigating the levels also appears here, and can be used to slow down enemies or heal your allies – it is almost always better to slow enemies, though, as that prevents them from doing damage (and makes it easier to interrupt them) much more than healing yourself does.
Unfortunately, after a while, the battles become a bit routine; while the first set of enemies in an area are new and fresh, after a while they become very routine and can be defeated via a very samey set of actions in the same way that Final Fantasy X fights often went. This makes many of the fights in the game fairly dull, and while they’re skippable, the bosses, which are much more difficult, basically require you to beat every other enemy in the game so that you’re the proper level to face them.
The boss encounters tend to be the highlight of the game; they’re the most enjoyable bits of it, and tend to be a bit different from other encounters, mostly in that the bosses and their companions tend to be more dangerous, quicker, and more prone to retaliation and inflicting annoying status ailments that require you to actually think on your feet. Even still, I got through the game without getting a single game over, and I suspect that most players will do so as well; indeed, I was left with an overabundance of items at the end of the game and used them with wild abandon against the final boss, as I had hardly used any prior to that point.
There is also an equipment system, in which craftable, equippable gems which are acquired over the course of the game are put into slots and have various static effects on a character and their statistics; these can be used to add elemental damage types to physical attacks, grant bonus damage, make a character tougher or more resilient, or even increase the rate of xp gain.
While this system seems neat in theory, I had the xp-gain gems equipped to my characters’ body slots for the entire game, and never needed to remove them to mitigate damage. Moreover, I pretty much figured out exactly how I was supposed to equip all of my characters quite early and from there on out it was just a matter of marginally improving my equipment over time – not the most exciting thing in the world, but it gave some sense of progression.


Presentation

The game is reasonably well-presented; the game tries to go for a sort of storybook style, with the characters appearing almost like paper cut-outs or things from a storybook, and the monsters having a similar stylized character. The music and sound are both reasonable enough, but a lot of the dialogue – delivered entirely in rhyme – is pretty awful. Sometimes it works well, but other times it falls down and is kind of painful to read.

Final Summary

Child of Light is not a bad game, but it isn’t exactly thrilling either. Everything about it is a decent enough idea, but in practice, it only shines on rare occasion. The game takes on the order of 20 hours to complete, and has no replay value; while there is a new game + mode, there is little reason to play it.

Child of Light narrate the story of a future princess that wish to save his father from his deadly lonelyness throught a long journey to a new world where she was sent away from her father.

The story, musics, voices and graphics make that game become a tantalizing work of art which will please teenagers and adults.

Fighting are subtles as you may have a lot of mechanisms to work with beginning witth your first partener a firefly. Your new partner will help you to slow down one ennemy or heal the wound of one of your partener at time using its own power. You will need the mouse? or the right controler stick to move him.

You'll then have a lot of friends to help you in your journey. All of them including you have their own skills, and a 3-branch skill tree to master. You can only use 2 character at time but can switch to another one when one of your ally is about to be ready.

Also during your quest you'll find some occuli shards, which after being crafted are stronger than before. Every occuli have its own power depending of the color and the size of it. An Occuli can be equipped to one of the three slots of each character. Finally Occulis have a different powers depending one which slot their are assigned.

The game difficulty can be set to normal or hard mode whenever you want. The hard mode make mostly bosses becoming real bosses as you'll need to be smarter than them. Some boss may be frustrating but preparing a strategy will help a lot to slay them all.

I can only strongely recommend you that game if you love RPG games !

Perhaps one of the most frustrating mechanism of the game is the interuption feature. But you can hope that the other ally will be hit or defend yourself waiting for the right time. You can also always rely on your firefly friend. So there is almost always a way to avoid that.

reviewText:
Child of Light is an extremely gorgeous piece of work. From its method of storytelling to its stunning visuals and appropriately airy and pleasant orchestral soundtrack, everything about this game's presentation ties together like a fine piece of poetry. Sure, the writing is a little clumsy at times, and they reeeeally stretch the language to hit the nail on the head for some of those rhymes (see what I did there?), but the heart is there and that's why Child of Light shines as brightly as it does. It just has a ton of heart and love in it and its creators' care for the project shines through and is ultimately infectious.

Child of Light's RPG elements are heavily inspired by Game Arts' Grandia series. Combat plays out with all characters assigned a spot on a timeline at the bottom of the screen. When a character or enemy hits a specific point on the timeline, they are then allowed to act. If a character or enemy is successfully attacked in the moments before their action is carried out, their attack is interrupted and they are pushed back on the timeline to hopefully try again. Combat mostly boils down to who can control the timeline better with their attacks or employing dirty tricks like slow down spells or status effects that inhitibt a character's movement on the timeline. All of the game's random battles have this strategic element, and boss fights even more so, which makes encounters not feel so mashy as RPGs can tend to be.

Combat is enhanced further by the way you customize your characters. Level ups grant skill points that you can spend on skill trees to grow your characters toward the stats and moves you want the most, though there's never any need to maximize any one part of a skill tree if you want your characters to do a little bit of everything. The Oculi system helps customization further by allowing you to imbue your characters with elemental attacks, defenses, and abilities to alter their or their enemy's stats on the timeline. These aren't the deepest systems ever, but they add enough depth to keep the character progression important.

So yeah, Child of Light is pretty awesome. Its only flaws are that it can be a tad too easy (I HIGHLY recommend throwing the difficulty up to Expert as soon as you have the ability to) and a character or two don't quite get their chances to shine in the story before the game wraps up. Other than that, fans of JRPGs will be incredibly happy with what Child of Light has to offer with its engrossing story, beautiful world, and solid RPG mechanics.

reviewText:
Final Impressions (01/11/2015; 15.5 hours playtime; Story Complete)

If and when some unfortunate woman bears my child, I will do everything within my power to have that kid play this game. What a delightful synthesis of fairy tales, story-telling, and JRPG mechanics. This truly is a great coming-of-age story that was unfortunately ignored due to Ubisoft's many misteps in 2014. But I have the excellent meltotheany to thank for bringing it to my attention as I originally stated.

The art direction in the game is fantastic. It really does look and feel like a children's fairy tale is playing out on screen. Moreover, the landscapes are varied and colorful, ranging from caves, forests, fires, castles, villages, etc.

I found the rhyming dialogue charming. In addition, the dialogue really serves to bolster the characters' different personalities and backgrounds, whether they be brave warriors or merchants with a savvy eye on profit. Background characters aren't fleshed out as much in dialogue, often repeating the same two-line rhyming couplet. But this is forgiveable as they are background characters. A select few that give quests offers up for extensive dialogue that relates their personality so it's clear that it could've been done. But I will give Ubisoft the benefit of the doubt in that that didn't want to overencumber the game with too much irrelevant dialogue for the sake of word-building. There's just enough in there to give a generalized sense of the tribes and their cultues.

As far as battle mechanics go, this was pretty interesting to me. I've played a handful of JRPGs in my time and this echoes the turn-based model. However, it brings an interesting twist. The player can interrupt enemy attacks by timing their attacks to occur in a limited time window, and vice versa. This really put me on the defensive more than I otherwise would, often trying to decide whether I should gamble on getting an attack in before my characters are hit or whether I should buckle down and defend to mitigate damage. In addition, the use of Igniculus (a firefly companion that the player can control with the mouse) helps in the tide of battle by slowing enemies down, healing your character, or activating one of two or three troves of health and mana. Equipment management is largely tossed aside (which I think is actually a pretty good idea) with the exception of oculi. Oculi are gemstones you collect and craft throughout the game which can be placed in one of three slots for various combat perks. The crafting system is simple and easy to understand with the use of a small chart that is provided and the player is left to their own imagination as far as experimenting with different combinations.

The story of the game is also superb. On the one hand, it is somewhat traditional. On the other, being a sort of video fairy tale this is perfectly fine and there are a couple of twists to be enjoyed through the narrative. Ultimately, the game is a coming of age story as we watch Aurora deal with the new problems she has been presented with. Both the music and the narration butterfly perfectly with the narrative. This is especially true of the narrator, which chokes me up a little bit and brings me back to thoughts of listening to my mother tell me stories or read me books.

From what I've read and experienced, many of the chracters are optional and are not required. The genius part is that this drastically affects gameplay, making the lone wolf much enjoy a much more difficult experience and a slightly stripped down story.

All in all, this is an excellent, charming game with a sweet soul. It seems to me that a lot of love and attention went into its development and it really reflects in the experience. I encourage anyone to purchase it and give it a go. And THEN, after you beat it, do a little research on things mentioned in the game as there is a grain of truth at the heart of the story.

First Impressions (01/08/2015; 7 hours playtime)

Child of Light answers the question of, What would've happened if fairy tales and video games were invented at the same time and co-evolved?" The music is beautiful. The art direction is fantastic. As it stands right now

reviewText:
I can't even begin to describe how GORGEOUS this game is! It's like you're literally inside a watercolor masterpiece world! I would put this on the same level as Okami for aesthetic value :) Yes, the rhyming does feel forced (because it is) especially during the dialogue, but that just adds to the quirky-ness of the Lemurian world.

I found the battle system interesting. It took me a while to get used to because I'd never played a game with this timer-turn-based strategy system (though I'm sure it's not the first of its kind). But once I got the hang of how it worked, I was surprised, and elated, by how thoughtful your moves need to be, particularly in boss battles, to be successful and effective. However, you could certainly get through this game by simply throwing your most powerful moves at the monsters, you just won't be nearly as efficient. Some may consider that a downside to the game, but I think it is an upside: you can progress through and enjoy the story whether you want to play strategically or not, allowing more skill levels to be able to enjoy the game.

There is also a significant amount of exploring you can do to find bonuses, which I simply loved. This game exceeded my expectations in every way, and I would highly recommend it to anyone! As of this review (about 16 hours of gameplay), I have completed the main plot and all of the side quests (that I have found anyway), but I still have a bit more exploration to do to find the remaining hidden items in all the areas.

I did experience a few glitches, such as Aurora's hair disappearing during battles and visual stutters near the end of the game, but nothing that effected gameplay.

reviewText:
Child of Light is brilliant. The artistic value of this game is remarkable: the hand-painted backgrounds are stunningly beautiful, the orchestrated soundtrack is melodious and enchanting. Everything together makes you feel like you're really in a fairy tale. Exploring (or better, flying over) Lemuria is an absorbing experience, I think I'll never get tired of it.
Fortunately, under the huge artistic value there's a good game. The RPG mechanics are simple, yet engaging. There are no random encounters: you can see the enemies on the map and decide whether to engage them or not. The combat system feels like a good ol' jRPG, revolving around anticipating/interrupting the enemies and party members swapping. You can also use your little firefly Igniculus to slow down enemies and heal yourself, adding a layer of complexity to the combat mechanics. This system feels fresh through the entire length of the game, so you'll just find yourself willingly engaging all the enemies, since fighting them is fun.

Even though everything seems swell and nice, Child of Light has some problems. Aurora is the only fleshed out and likeable character. The other characters are just... there, they don't make a difference. The whole game is written in rhyme, which seems cool, but it's not: the metric is all over the place, it's not consistent at all. In the end it didn't bother me, but it could bother you. The plot is simple, a standard (maybe a bit darker) fairy tale plot. I liked it anyway, it's a good justification to explore Lemuria and to flesh out Aurora's personality, but if you're seeking a complex plot you're looking at the wrong game.

In the end, is it worth 15 euro? Absolutely, it's worth more than that. We need more games like Child of Light, we need more middle ground between Indie and AAA titles. If you're on the fence, it's time to jump and buy this game. ;0

reviewText:
No matter how good a game is, or how much I enjoy/enjoyed it, I normally don't feel compelled to write a review for it. But, man...this game. After nearly having a coronary from Dark Souls 2, Child of Light was a very welcome respite that just melted the rage away. The music is well done and the evironments are beautiful (the giant walking in the background near the starting part of the game was a very nice touch), and the dialogue is fun (but maybe that's just the English major in me talking, even though I've never been much of a poet). The gameplay itself is straight forward and easy to get a handle on while still requiring a bit of forethought and attention. It's also kind of refreshing to have a little girl who is undoubtedly strong in her own right as the main character. Haven't finished the game yet, no idea how far in I am, but I did have to force myself to stop playing so I could stretch things out over the course of a few days instead of greedily devouring it all at once.

Unlike what seems to be a majority of people, I haven't had any problems with the UPlay aspect (with this game or with Far Cry 3 or Might and Magic) so that isn't an issue for me.

I also bought all the Day 1 DLC just to spite the a-holes who throw hissy fits about it. So let me end this pleasant review of an excellent game by saying to the haters: lol u mad?

reviewText:
Yes, it uses uPlay, but the game is so great I need to recommend it anyway.

Regarding uPlay: When it functions how it's intended to (as it did for me), after you set up an account and register the game via CD key, the game launches straight from Steam, and just leaves the uPlay window in the background. After some simple settings, the only interaction you need to have with it is closing the window when you quit the game.

Regarding the game: It's a pseudo-real-time turn-based RPG set in a fairy tale world, wrapped up in a fairy tale story with fairy tale narration. Everything is in rhyme, and while the story really isn't too complex or gripping, it has a gentle nostalgic feel to it. The timing of the combat adds a fresh twist to the stale formula JRPGs have used forever, making each battle feel more real and alive.

The cast is diverse, yet the characters are flat- I didn't especially care for any of them, and there was one in particular that just got on my nerves. But the simplicity of their design fits in nicely with the simplicity of the story, and they each have their own little story which helps flesh out the world a little more.

To put it simply- This game is like playing through a bedtime story. For the most part, there isn't much depth, but the game doesn't lead you to believe otherwise. All it asks of you is that you listen, you enjoy, and you embrace this enchanted world. It's a great, simple experience.

reviewText:
Child of Light is a 2d Metroidvania turn-based RPG in which a young Princess, named Aurora, wakes up in a mythical land known as Lemuria. In order to return home she needs to find the powers of the Sun and Moon but a sinister plot gets in her way. She finds creatures from all walks of life to help her in her journey, each with their own special power.

The artwork is really really good especially if you have an affinity for oil based and watercolor style paintings. The game worked perfectly with my Xbox360 controller and a 2nd player can control Igniculus the firefly with a mouse or 2nd controller too. The combat is a mildly complex paper-rock-scissors system (almost exactly like South Park: Stick of Truth) which has a timeline that shows which order the characters/monsters will attack (much like the Grandia games). It can be difficult to use in the beginning but by the end of the game nothing stood a chance against me even on expert. There is a skill tree that has 3 branching paths/playstyles for each character. There is also a crafting system for gems (Oculi) that you can equip on the character's weapon, armor or accessory to give it different effects and bonuses. There isn't much complexity in terms of platforming seeing as how you get the ability to fly early on and from there it's about not getting hurt by environmental hazards. It's a well made and beautiful game with a fitting classical-hybrid soundtrack. One thing that might be off-putting for people is the dialog, written in poetry form with rhyming. I got used to it though and found it less annoying the more I played.

I played it for about 8 hours my first time through and got sidetracked with other stuff and stopped. I came back to it 2 years later and finished the game with ~16 hours logged in on my save file. Was it worth the $15 I paid for it? Yes. I'd say this is a pretty solid game well worth the asking price but even better if you can get it on sale.

reviewText:
Child of Light is that game that every gamer should play just to relax, listening to it's awesome soundtracks and to realize in the process that even small games deserve much appreciation. Now, the game is in 2D, portraying great art style of a land ruled by a Dark Queen and her forces which you as a Child of Light must fight to return peace to it's inhabitants. The story might sound very familiar but what must be taken into account is the way it is told. The pacing is precise and the dialogues are well written. The gameplay is simple and enjoyable, moving around and exploring different areas of the land of lemuria, collecting various items, turn-based fighting various enemies and a few bosses here and there, leveling up your character, crafting occuli (gems combined for various effects applicable to gear), solving a few simple puzzles and completing few side quests. The game length is around 20hrs if not rushed. I find it real value as the game is beautifully done overall.


WHY YOU SHOULD GET THIS:

+ Epic soundtrack, especially during fights
+ Visual Design
+ RPG/ Turn-Based style of gameplay
+ Party management
+ Well paced story and events that can move your heart
+ Not too long and not too short


NEGATIVES:

- Light vs Dark story is enjoyable but we've heard it before (not a big negative)
- More side quests and more bosses/enemy variety would have been awesome


OVERALL:  85/100

reviewText:
This game carries its own little charm. Artistically, it calls back to the watercolour art of fairy tale books. Looking at it is incredibly nostalgic, since I used to read books like this as a child. Even the narrative is reminiscent of the best of fairy tale tropes, though the game manages to sneak in its own details and wit that keep the story feeling fresh and light. Even the characters are unique, with our heroine Aurora experiencing a coming of age story but still retaining a spunky attitude.

The best thing this game has to offer is the absolutely fantastic musical score that helps to create the atmosphere of Lemuria. The songs are emotional, they can be light, and they can be dark, all accentuating points throughout the game. And nothing is as good as the amazing boss battle music, with a male choir singing as you slice your way through hordes of monsters.

The turn based system was really interesting to see, and I really enjoyed how they implemented it into the game. The twist with the turn based mechanic is a sort of wait" or "charge up" time

Don't let the cute exterior of this fantastically designed game fool you.  Beneath the cute, cherubic face of the main character, Aurora, lies a deep plot of betrayal, death, despair, witty dialogue, and complex emotional situations.  While the characters speak largely in prose, sometimes the rhyming seems a bit forced or tedious, but overall, this doesn't detract from the appeal of this game.  You may need a dictionary or thesaurus handy for some lines, as Ubi is definitely flexing their literary muscles with this title.

UbiArt has found the perfect fusion between picturesque platforming adventure games and true, turn-based classic rpgs.  Using a battle system somewhat reminiscent of the battle systems in Final Fantasy 6 through 10 and a skill system something like out of 10 and 11, the player is given an experience that will probably be familiar, but with new aspects to it, such as the ability to choose an enemy to slow down.  The combat system is further diversified with the use of special crystals that the characters can equip in order to enhance various combat abilities.

I just spent two days marathoning this game on hard and feeling very satisfied with what I had played.  While somewhat short in terms of rpgs at roughly 20 hours without DLC, there's no shortage of things to do in the game.  The tendency to skip battles will be high with the ability to simply fly around many of them, but you may not want to.  Boss battles tend to be pretty hard and need a good bit of planning to get through.  I'm honestly not sure if that holds true on lower difficulties.  One nice feature of the game is that if you've missed a side quest or mini-quest along the way, that's not a problem.

I think the two best features of this game are the local co-op and the use of the light-based puzzles.  The second player takes control of Igniculus, a small light elemental that helps Aurora at the start of her adventure.  Using either the mouse or the second player controller (controllers work best in this game, imo), the second player can move around, gather items for the player, light up rooms, and slow down enemies.   This is a great feature for gamers with kids that actually want to take part in their parent's activities.  Even if they don't listen to you and go off and do their own thing, it won't be devastatingly bad, except maybe during a boss battle.

The light puzzles caught me offguard at first, but once I got used to them, they were fairly easy, yet still interesting.  More games integrating puzzles into their gameplay could definitely learn from the examples in this game.  I nearly got thrown off by one puzzle at the Gate to the Palace of the Sun, but was able to figure it out with some careful observation.

The soundtrack for this game is amazingly well done.  Songs are sufficiently long enough that being stuck on a stage doesn't become an experience of wanting to pull your ears off of your head, and the boss music is sufficiently epic for fighting demons, dragons, and things of that sort.  Perhaps even more fittingly epic than many other games that I've played.

reviewText:
So good that I played it twice, back to back!

Child of Light reminds me in some ways of Studio Ghibli movies: they have a childish aesthetic but are more mature in story and tone. There is an unmistakable somber quality throughout Child of Light, something I wouldn't have expected from a game with a whimsical watercolor art style. This game excels at bringing together elements from various genres and fusing them together into a shining example of innovation for the industry.

Let me list a few of the highlights of the game before I get into a few critiques. This is a gorgeous game, like a living painting with fantastic use of color, interesting inhabitants and exquisite backgrounds. The music stood out from the start and meshed perfectly with the overall tone. The combat showed its depth when I got my greatest enjoyment out of it during my second time through (New Game+ on Hard). A simple but satisfying crafting system allows for customization without too much complexity. Dialogue written in poetry combined with a chapter structure and occasional video cutscenes all add to the moving storybook feel of the game.

Unfortunately this game is not perfect. Some of my complaints, particularly the first one, are matters of personal taste so you'll have to decide for yourself whether what I'm describing sounds like something that would bother you or not. I'm not much of a fan of poetry. At times I did enjoy the rhyming dialogue but other times it seemed like the writers were doing verbal backflips to fit the rhyme in, which made it feel forced and/or obscured the meaning. I do appreciate the novelty of it and how it lends itself to the storybookesque design. Some may dismiss the game as a kid's game due to the childish visuals or playing as a young girl but I urge you not to make that mistake.

Without spoiling anything, I will simply say that the ending felt like it came rather abruptly but was otherwise satisfying. There was a point roughly 2/3rds of the way through my first playthrough that the combat became boring for a time. I was afraid going into my 2nd playthrough (New Game+) that I would be bored with the combat during most of it but that turned out not to be true. The level of challenge on Hard kept me on my toes and making use of all my party member's specialties. I must say that potions are fairly useless in the game. I only used about a dozen in total. Also, don't expect any complex puzzles or platforming. You can fly from nearly the start of the game so traditional platforming goes out the window in favor of mostly manipulating things with your firefly sidekick. Controlling both Aurora with WASD and Igniculus (firefly) with the mouse keeps things interesting.

If I haven't mentioned any aspect you're wondering about go ahead and assume it's good, this game simply oozes quality.

reviewText:
As a player of console-style RPGs, I'm really happy this game exists.  It's a beautiful example of how art direction can add so much to solid gameplay and a classic, if well-worn, story.  The game's combat system is really easy for any veteran of the genre (which is why they included a Hard mode), but works well and integrates well into the tactics you can do with your party.  It's solid, it's fun, and it strikes that balance where battles don't frustrate you into hating whenever they crop up, but they also interest you enough to put thought into the fight.

It's really the art direction that sells this game, though.  Everything is a dreamy watercolor and ink, perfectly suited for a children's story book.  Coupled with the excellent music, I found myself completely involved in Aurora's adventure, wanting her to succeed and happy that I was there helping her out in a way.  I cringed at her bare feet on the rocky ground, chuckled at every time she had to sternly correct people that she wasn't a princess, smiled at her childish and loving dialogue, fought not to cry at her moment of despair, and sometimes even found myself staring in awe as she took on grim creatures for the sake of Lemuria and her friends.

It's a fairy tale, so don't expect any plot twists, but it makes no bones about what it is, and as such people who come in expecting to be sucker-punched should probably stick with the games that do that kind of plot, like OFF or The Witch's House.  This isn't to say that the game lacks emotional torque; I've found it very difficult to get past teary-eyed even at the most intense moments in games I've played, and this thing had me fighting not to cry around the midway point.  I knew every last thing that would happen, and yet the telling was beautiful enough to make it seem fresh and new.  That's the core of it, really; it could have easily fallen apart with how cliched everything could be said to be, but it believes so deeply in its story that I ended up believing too, and that experience is what makes the difference.

reviewText:
I'm not entirely sure what drew me to Child of Light.  Was it the beautiful watercolor art?  The plaintive music?  The little girl that reminded me of my own daughter?  All I can say is that the previews exhibited an intangible quality that made the game one that I had to purchase.

First and foremost, Child of Light is a classic fairy tale, told simply and in a straightforward manner.  It is filled with the tropes one might expect - wicked stepmother, lost child, an impossible quest - and is also possessed of the melancholy that the best fairy tales have, a feeling intensified by the haunting flute melody.  This effect is also heightened by the beautiful art direction.  I felt like I was watching a painted book illustration come to life, and when I first started the game, I spent a minute or two just marvelling at the way Aurora's hair swirled as if underwater.

Child of Light is also a role-playing game, and although some of its mechanics fall short, the main battle system is wonderfully and unexpectedly engaging.  The basic concept is simple: during combat a single time bar shows who is the next to act, whether it be a member of your party or a monster.  Chosen actions and haste attributes affect how long it takes to reach the end of the bar and perform your action.  And if you hit a monster (or vice versa) in the small space of time right before it acts, you interrupt the creature and send it flying back down the time bar.

This one modification to a pretty standard combat system adds a layer of excitement and calculation.  Chain-interrupting a monster over and over again feels utterly dominating; trying to ensure that your party avoids interruption can be nerve-wrackingly tense.  And when you encounter later monsters and bosses that punish you for interrupting them, the sudden scramble to figure out an appropriate strategy is enjoyably frenetic.

The supporting game systems - skill trees, potions, gem crafting - are less polished, almost like afterthoughts.  Rather than enhancing the play, they feel like something tacked on just to give the player additional things to do.  That leads to another potential criticism: Child of Light is not the most difficult game, and someone yearning for challenging depth may be disappointed.

Add my feeling that the ending was a bit abrupt, and the conclusion is that Child of Light could have done with a few more coats of polish.  That being said, I still loved my time playing the game, the sensation of falling from the present into a magical and wondrous world.  For me, Child of Light is an easy game to recommend.

--- Closing Eyes is Magic ---

reviewText:
I'm deeply ambivalent about Child of Light.  Its target demographic seems to be tween girls, which doesn't quite describe me, but I did find it engaging enough to spend the 18-ish hours of a complete play-through with all the side quests -- well, nearly all; about which more later.  Despite that, though, I finished with the sense that it's simply not that good overall.  I'm glad I only paid $15 for it.

On the one hand, much of the game is frankly gorgeous.  The watercolor world,, layered and constantly in motion behind the primary action, is brilliantly done.  So is the character animation while roaming that world: Aurora's hair billowing around her is nearly a character in its own right, and adorable.  There's a great deal to be said for a game that is purely wonderful just to look at.

On the other hand... it's not a particularly good game.  The most that can be said for it is that the difficulty ramp is tuned fairly well, with the significant foes in the final stages of the game being approximately as challenging as the corresponding ones in the early stages.  Beyond that, well... there's a great deal of repetition, of oh

reviewText:
While many would call this a children's title based off its presentation and appearance, it has a bit of depth in terms of a complex and somewhat fun combat system.  Its difficulty can be a bit underwhelming at times, but battles place a heavy reliance on planning, buffs, timing, interrupting enemy attacks whilst preventing your own from being disrupted and your usual RPG elements.  Namely, elemental weaknesses or some enemies being heavily resistant to physical attacks, but crumble under magic.  Or those that stage counterattacks to physical attacks, etc.  That part feels very Final Fantasy.

Unfortunately, the depth and sense of achievement that would come from this Active Time Battle inspired element disappears when the game's relatively low difficulty comes into effect.  You are never in such danger, even by the midgame, that a health potion or a debuff spell doesn't completely turn the tides in your favor.  To that end, I do feel the game was intended for a younger audience.

Nitpicking aside, it holds very true to being a digital fairytale - if a somewhat dry one.  The story is not particularly engaging, so most of what will carry you along is the combat system and the overall charm the world itself presents.  There are mountains walking about with cities on their backs, visible in some area backgrounds far in the distance and that you scale from the ground up that gives some good flavor to the world overall.  But the slow pace of the story makes the beautiful watercolor backdrops something you'd probably be more satisfied taking in bites rather than trying to playing the whole game through in one sitting.

Overall, it's a decent attempt.  It could do with a few more engaging or deep elements, but it is what it is - an indie-game-lookalike with a decent combat system and some charming decor.

reviewText:
This side scrolling RPG game is full of gorgeous art, tells a heartfelt story and has classic turnbased gameplay. It just has a little problem with details.


POSITIVES -

And honestly if that's what you want in a game, Child of Light is completely for you. Its gameplay is very simple, a little repetitive and not complicated, like the usual RPG. It'll throw in stat boosts, debuffs and a rock paper scissors formula as the game goes on, but nothing that's too difficult or new. So if you're fine with that old school feel, you'll be impressed with the game.

The art is painted, water colored and ... well, amazing. The music ranges from soft and to intense; the developer really knew what she was doing. The atmosphere is also done so well, from the dark and moody beginning, to the huge and open bright fields after you've gained your new powers.

And really the feel of this game is what helps the story. You play as a young girl named Aurora who's been thrown down the rabbit hole, everything straight out of an old child book. And it really works. This coming-of-age tale is detailed and imaginative, but still very simple. It's a tale of good vs. evil, growing up and even tragedy. Running through a lonely and dark forest in the beginning of the game, only to shout a cheer when you gain your wings and sword, it just feels triumphant. Our main protagonist goes from being a slightly selfish princess and child, to someone who takes on responsibility, even if it means making tough decisions and charging into a dark world that isn't so different from our own.

NEGATIVES -

The few problems of Child of Light are mainly its tedious puzzles, lack of development in its side cast and rushed ending.

I had no problem with the old feel of gameplay or skill set, like some people do. But after hours of playing the game, even in its last dungeon, you'll be maneuvering around the same spikes, pushing boxes and following clues you've seen before. It would have been nice to have a little more variety.

The side characters are extremely endearing filled with personality, even if a little cliché. But after their initial introduction, they barely get any extra personal touch and their problems don't get mentioned or resolved until the end of the game...

...which is rushed. And that's unfortunate, because it's VERY rushed. The game has a way of giving a good poetic feel when it comes to its plot. And certain things in this sort of fantasy setting aren't meant to make complete sense, but Child of Light still has it all structured. So it's pretty jarring when the game ends rather quickly, really quickly. It resolves everything, but it seems much more forced than everything you've been through so far. And certain plot twists and events don't get explained fully or at all at the end.

CONCLUSION -

Child of Light is really an amazing game and one of my favorites for 2014. It has everything put together so well and it’s just lovely. But the details are sometimes a little muddy.

Those issues didn't distract me enough though to not HIGHLY RECOMMEND this game to anyone.

Wonderful. Bravo. I want a sequel.

reviewText:
Look, i'm not the type of person who usually plays these kind of games. I tend to stick with larger Tripple A titles from larger companies, and may sometimes jump into smaller, 2D, indie or story based games, but this game just blew me away.

The mixture of a great story with a fantastic soundtrack, and beautiful art design (so good). I remember exploring this world and seeing the amazing mountains and buildings in the background, and once even noticed a giant walking in the distance. The beauty of the game really blew me away, and the beautiful soundtrack made it better. It was so beautiful and fun exploring this world, and it left me wanting more when I finished. The combat was intense, interesting and really fun as well. I was really satisfied everytime I won a battle. The boss battles were really the highlight of the combat in my opinion. I had more fun fighting the bosses than the actual creatures you come across while exploring, and this is obviously how it should be.
The only negative thing I came across was that the menu was so obviouly made for consoles. It was awkward navigating at times and I often made mistakes, but it's something that I got used to and didn't mind too much, it's only a slight issue.

Overall it's a great game that you should buy. 9/10 for those who care about scores...

reviewText:
Even though Child of Light is tagged as a platformer, the tactical battles play a much more significant role in the game. It's a unique and engaging system where success depends on selecting the right characters for the encounter, utilizing the skills in an intelligent way, and a unique system of timing the attacks. Beautiful visuals are accompanied by exellent music. Music I'd actually listen to outside of the game.

I almost quit playing after tiring of forced rhymes, and a story I wasn't that invested in. Around the middle of the game, I started enjoying the story a bit more. There were times when the story touched an emotional chord.

Combat could become a little repetitive, but a new challenge usually wasn't too far around the corner so I persevered during those times. The music in the final battle was like a reward for my persistence. Controlling the flow of combat with Igniculus was rewarding in its own right, just as much as selecting the right characters for a particular encounter and making smart skill choices.

A new game+ mode exists for those looking for more, but I think it is a 1 playthrough type of game. A playthrough which I enjoyed more than I first thought I would. For a more detailed review please see my  full review.[www.oneguytoomanygames.com]

reviewText:
This year has been pretty kind to turn based RPGs. On the PC, first came South Park: The Stick of Truth and now Child of Light.

This game has a pretty unique art style which evokes a fairy tale in the player's mind. The entire game has a rhyme scheme going on with its dialogue which is interesting to say the least. The whole band of characters is likeable and man....the music.....the music will leave you spellbound.

The story is fairy tale material. I am 9 chapters into the game and it is pretty compelling. I am quite curious to see how it all ends.

Lastly the combat is surprisingly deep for a game worth 15 bucks. There are status elements to remember and exploit. There is a crafting system as well. The combat animations are well done and there is also a real time element to the turn based combat which makes the fights real tense.

Steam says I have been playing this game for 20+ hours though that is a big lie as that figure is inflated as I forgot to exit uplay most times after quitting the game(I am sure I have played for 10+ hours). Coming to uplay, it's integration is painless and you won't even notice it's there. They seem to have finally got cloud saves enabled so I don't have to lose my save games again (thank god for that).

All in all, if you are pining for the JRPGs of yore, Child of Light will cure that itch.

reviewText:
It's like crime how Child of Light can rob you of your time.

The combination of side-scrolling exploration, challenging turn-based tactical gameplay, amusing rhyming dialogues and a wonderful art style makes Child of Light an unusual but enjoyable gem.

You'll quickly fall in love with the beatifully drawn landscapes of Lemuria as you travel through its dark forests, mountains and even under the sea. They are typically riddled with secret areas you can sniff out for treasure, puzzles or hidden bosses. Often there'll be more than one path to your destination, making exploration more interesting.

During your travels, you'll meet many fun characters who'll give your quests, join you in your adventure, or both. My favourite was a female jester who couldn't do the dialogues in a proper rhyming fashion, allowing the other characters to jump in and correct her. Her healing abilities were also very welcome in a fight, making her one of my most used characters during combat.

The combat is turn-based but has a real-time element that lets you delay enemies' turn or slightly heal your party out of turn. Timing this ability is important to winning encounters, as it lets you better use or avoid being the victim of the interrupt mechanic. Interrupting means hitting a character trying to perform an action, resulting in his turn being delayed. If you don't go for the easy difficulty, combat offers good and rewarding challenge that makes you invest time into considering how to specialise your characters.

Each character has a network of specialisation trees, offering abilities unique to him while giving you a choice between the different paths. For example, there's a wizard who can specialise in lightning, water or fire, allowing him to excel against certain creature types vulnerable to his focused element. Another character can choose between improving his defense, his offense or his ability to direct enemy attacks against him.

A problem that grows as the size of your party increases, is the frequency of level ups. Very quickly you'll be looking at one or multiple level ups after pretty much every battle as your characters gain levels and extra skill points to spend. It becomes tedious looking at the skill tree menu this often.

Another part of character customisation is the Oculi system. Oculi are gems you gather and can use kind of like equipment items such as swords and armor in other games. They offer different bonuses depending on color and slot used, and can be combined to form more powerful gems. Oculi juggling gets a little cumbersome, but is nonetheless an important strategic element as you want to equip the right damage and resistance types depending on the opposition of your current area.

Apart from having trouble with Steam starting the game through Uplay for some reason initially, the only bug I noticed in the actual game was that sometimes when entering combat, Aurora's (the main character) usually flowing hair wasn't drawn.

If you're not playing on Easy difficulty and like to explore and look for secrets, you should expect around 20 hours of gameplay from Child of Light.


TIP: While Child of Light offers controller support, I really must recommend using mouse and keyboard. You will need the precision to properly manage the real-time element of the otherwise turn-based combat.

TIP: If, like me, you have trouble starting the game through Steam, try launching Uplay directly and start the game from there. After doing that, it's been working for me no problem.

reviewText: I recommend this game because it's not bad. But bear in mind I'm really disappointed. After having a great time with Valiant Hearts I thought it was a good idea to give a chance to another small Ubisoft game. But Child of Light is not like Valiant Hearts at all. First, the story is lame at best. It's not interesting for anyone above 7 years old and the way it's told makes it even worst. The game tells its story with rhymes, like a poem, which is cool at first, but boring after some minutes. It's because they just couldn't write the story using rhyming during for a 7 hours game. The failed attempts to rhyme every single dialogue make the story hard to follow and button to skip very attractive. The good is: the art style is gorgeous, perfect for some screenshots, making this game easily one of the prettiest games out there right now. I wish they had voice acting for the dialogues and I'm not really a big fan of turn-based combat, but it works. Another complaint is about the difficulty. There's only two modes: casual and hard (or veteran, I don't remember anymore). And they're complete opposites, being the former extremely easy and the latter extremely hard. There's no middle ground and that sucks. I have to say it again, the game is not bad, but it's far from the masterpiece I was expecting. Maybe next time they'll try less hard to make some artistic masterpiece and do a real masterpiece :( (For the ones who care about empowered women in games, there's no better example on steam, I just want to say I couldn't care less about that)

reviewText:
Child of Light is a fairytale roleplaying game in the vein of many fondly remembered children's stories.  Aurora, first born princess of the Austrian King, falls to illness and is transported to the fantastical land of Lemuria--a kingdom of monsters and anthropomorphic animals alike.  It is in both the adequately written prose and beautiful illustrations that one feels they are interacting in a proper storybook.  The gameplay also draws from a long-line of classic influences; side-scrolling areas are subtle in their similarities to Metroid-vania games, while the battle system is turn-based and real-time with a smattering of Grandia's system of delaying and interrupting actions with carefully timed attacks.

The combination of beautiful illustrations, a lullaby-like soundtrack, and a nostalgic battle system enticed me to return each day to learn a little more about Aurora's newfound whereabouts.  While dialogue between characters is again illustrated with beautiful character profiles, the conversations themselves can feel a little contrived at times--granted, I would snicker here and there.  Each part of Lemuria is broken up by chapters and again highlight the range of beauty that the game's artists are capable of showing us.  Animations are smooth and the use of lighting for backgrounds and objects really adds to the fantasy.

In the end, I found myself enjoying Child of Light for what it was trying to be; an interactive storybook that subtly entices you to turn each page carefully and deliberately in the hopes that you'll get lost in it.  At the same time, I was disappointed by that very thing--a mostly pretty game with a fun story that doesn't demand that you invest in their characters beyond some archetypical quirks.

reviewText:
This game just flat out awed me and filled me so full of nostalgic feelings for the RPGs I played on my Playstation when I was a young girl. What I love most was the battle system which was a slightly more dynamic version of the turn-based Active Time Battle system used in many older Final Fantasy games. The visuals are beautiful and the story is entertaining and poetic. I thoroughly enjoyed all the different party members and the game's plot.

Literally, my only disappointment is I wish this game was longer, because I didn't want it to end so soon. Also, it requires Uplay, a client provided through Ubisoft. Based on other reviews, it appears to be finicky. But I didn't seem to experience any problems with it. Even after I had nearly stopped playing the game for a year and went back to play it again later, I incurred no serious issues with the Uplay service.

If you're into RPGs you should definitely give this game a try. And if you're not too familiar with the style of RPGs, don't worry. This game is straight forward, easy to get into and quite intuitive when it comes to controls.

reviewText:
Not a bad little rpg, i originally was captured by the artstyle and continued to play on.
It has a nice feel to flying and a lot of the fluidity feels like the honed gameplay from some of the recent rayman games. Infact i can imagine them just taking the straight rayman engine and loading it up with these cartoony/storybook assets.

Anyway the game started out strong for me, an interesting story and art style and game mechanics but after a while those things get stale. Most puzzles involve using Igniculus to shine on some element or to project a shadow. I thought you might get other abilities other than flying but you don't. Then i also found myself skipping alot of the dialog which i rarely do in games, i think its just due to the fact its not straightforward chit chat.

All in all though it was fun enough to push through, the other characters and pickups and parts of the story were intersting enough and i could see some different experiences happening between players if you don't seek out every single thing in the game.

I can see a sequel or another game of a similar style really tightening up some of these aspects and making a much better rounded experience.

reviewText: Child of Light seemed, like it has the tools to be a really good game: Interesting story, nice combat and really good graphics. But after a while, dodging optional fights became common and I had to force myself to fight the optional enemies (otherwise the bossfights would become impossible) and the expirience slowed down a lot and became very repetetive and boring. reviewText:
Though there is some fun to be had here, it felt like the story and pacing really unravelled into a mess by the end which colored the experience badly. CONS:

- clear best strategy once you get most of the characters that never was challenged

reviewText:
(disclaimer: I had heard that this game was easy so I played it on the harder difficulty, this may have underlined some of the faults and influenced my opinion)

The overworld and sub-quests are not bad, but I won't go into much detail, because plenty of people talk about them.
My complaint is with the interruption system in combat. If a character is attacked while preparing an action, they get knocked back on the timeline. The problem is that this is a feast or famine system; you're either obliterating the enemy or caught in an unwinnable situation.
In the second half of the game, there are enemy combinations who will caste haste on their entire team and slow on your team. Add to that, that there can be 3 enemies, but only 2 of you. This leads to battles where you're consistently getting knocked back or put into a situation where all you can do is block or try to heal (basically never being able to damage the enemies to give yourself a chance). Then, you try the fight again and get a bit luckier (or are better equiped) and win easily in 2-3 turns.
It really feels unbalanced, and I didn't enjoy it.

reviewText: If you're looking for a turn-based combat rpg then this is well worth picking up when it is on sale for under $5.  The environment is beautiful and the first couple hours of gameplay have a great story and then it feels like the writers started to get lazy or maybe there was less budget available.  After a while the combat starts to get really repetitive with no new abilities to mix things up.  It really seems like there was very little thought into balancing the skills and party members available - what ends up happening is that there are 2 characters are the end of the game which (if leveled correctly) vastly overpower the others and make combat trivial.\n\nOverall this game has about a 8 - 10 hours of non-repetitive entertainment so I'd suggest holding off purchase until your hours to $$$s ratio is at least 1:1.

reviewText:
Outstanding presentiation and music, and that's all.
The skill system is simply bad, you can choose between 3 branches per character but they differentiate for 3 or 4 different upgrades to spell you already start with. The gameplay wants to be different with the introduction of a fairy that will slow enemies or heal your characters as long as it has energy that will deplete using it. There's a little bit of depth in the fact that you need to exploit weaknesses to win fight, and there's a vast array of buffs and debuffs, but you can only use 2 characters and they have 2/3 spells each ... so yeah ...
I also found disappointing how they fit the amazing world art into a generic 2d sidescroller.
I tried to like this game but i really couldn't. You may like it if you are new to turn based rpg.

reviewText:
TLDR:  6 / 10
I would recommend this game to people who are looking for something simple and atmospheric to fill up a weekend and don't mind installing Uplay.


Details:

Positive:
-Great artwork / atmosphere
-Interesting take on turn based combat
-Challenging on expert
-Variant ways to progress each character
-Moderatly interesting boss fights

Negatives:
-Uplay required
-Story is incredibly mundane (though if you love fairy tales you probably will enjoy it)
-Very short game considering its cost (9 or 10 hours if you're collecting everything)
-Constant levels, every fight you have to click through level up animations
-Pix can act while you are waiting to choose an action meaning you can heal almost to full outside of the game timeline (i felt like i was cheating every time i did this).
-Crafting Oculi seems designed for a longer game

reviewText:
Ususally, I don't play turn-based games. I don't like that you have to wait a preordained period of time to be able to do something (where's my freedom to do whatever I want?!), so I bought this game on a whim. I liked the art mostly. It's cute. And it was on sale.

So with my bias against turn-based games, I started playing it, thinking ˝Well, if I don't like it, at least I didn't spend that much on it˝. And to my surprise, I kept on playing it. I did not feel frustrated about the turn-based system, because this game's system is more dynamic (play the game or youtube it and you'll see what I mean). As with all turn-based games, the fights can become repetitive, but I found them to be engaging enough to not really care about it.

I haven't finished the game yet, but so far I found the story to be quite engaging and well narrated. The rhymes add a taste of childhood, without being childish. The art is stunning and the soundtrack is well matched with the pacing of the game.

Overall, this game was a very pleasant surprise for me.

reviewText:
Child of Light is a fairytale roleplaying game in the vein of many fondly remembered children's stories.  Aurora, first born princess of the Austrian King, falls to illness and is transported to the fantastical land of Lemuria--a kingdom of monsters and anthropomorphic animals alike.  It is in both the adequately written prose and beautiful illustrations that one feels they are interacting in a proper storybook.  The gameplay also draws from a long-line of classic influences; side-scrolling areas are subtle in their similarities to Metroid-vania games, while the battle system is turn-based and real-time with a smattering of Grandia's system of delaying and interrupting actions with carefully timed attacks.

The combination of beautiful illustrations, a lullaby-like soundtrack, and a nostalgic battle system enticed me to return each day to learn a little more about Aurora's newfound whereabouts.  While dialogue between characters is again illustrated with beautiful character profiles, the conversations themselves can feel a little contrived at times--granted, I would snicker here and there.  Each part of Lemuria is broken up by chapters and again highlight the range of beauty that the game's artists are capable of showing us.  Animations are smooth and the use of lighting for backgrounds and objects really adds to the fantasy.

In the end, I found myself enjoying Child of Light for what it was trying to be; an interactive storybook that subtly entices you to turn each page carefully and deliberately in the hopes that you'll get lost in it.  At the same time, I was disappointed by that very thing--a mostly pretty game with a fun story that doesn't demand that you invest in their characters beyond some archetypical quirks.

reviewText:
This game just flat out awed me and filled me so full of nostalgic feelings for the RPGs I played on my Playstation when I was a young girl. What I love most was the battle system which was a slightly more dynamic version of the turn-based Active Time Battle system used in many older Final Fantasy games. The visuals are beautiful and the story is entertaining and poetic. I thoroughly enjoyed all the different party members and the game's plot.

Literally, my only disappointment is I wish this game was longer, because I didn't want it to end so soon. Also, it requires Uplay, a client provided through Ubisoft. Based on other reviews, it appears to be finicky. But I didn't seem to experience any problems with it. Even after I had nearly stopped playing the game for a year and went back to play it again later, I incurred no serious issues with the Uplay service.

If you're into RPGs you should definitely give this game a try. And if you're not too familiar with the style of RPGs, don't worry. This game is straight forward, easy to get into and quite intuitive when it comes to controls.

reviewText:
First and foremost, WOW. I was rather skeptical when I got this game, not sure if I will enjoy a turn-based RPG as I normally play action/ FPS. But since this game had Overwhelmingly Positive reviews, and the fact that I could get it cheap, I decided to give it a try.

I was pretty thorough with my play-through and clocked a total of 13.7 hours. And the thing is, I enjoyed every moment of it. I didn't complete it in one sitting (obviously) but I think it was three. I kept playing on and on and I think part of the reason was the battles. As mentioned, it is turn-based RPG with a focus on a timeline (some mentioned that the Final Fantasy series use this mechanic, but I'm new to it). There is no guarantee that you can even cast your spell, and sometimes you even lose the fight having done completely no action. There is some strategy involved and fights can be frustrating especially in Hard mode. It was new for me and I really liked it.

Apart from the battle system, there is also the crafting system worth mentioning. You collect these sorta gems from chests or from battle drops and you can combine them to form more refined versions or hybrid versions. For example, ruby + sapphire + emerald = diamond ; and 3 x ruby = bigger ruby. Equipping these gems in different slots give different stats that can help you in the battle.

The story is fine, nothing spectacular/ mind-blowing like in Bioshock Infinite, but it flows smoothly just like a Disney classic. The artwork is really well done too.

I really enjoyed this game, and I look forward to upcoming games of this genre.

10/10

reviewText:
Child of Light is one of the best games I've played in 2014. Its art and soundtrack work harmoniously and smoothly, you can spend HOURS playing without getting tired. Unlike AAA titles, CoL has no explosions, blood, violence - that kind of action. At the same time, it finds a balance where there will be a game that you won't sleep because of the lack of action. Even more if you are familiar with turn-based RPGs.

The rhyming story is well constructed and developed by charismatic characters with unique characteristics. Some details about the game interface has bothered me (like not being able to organize my party) but it weren't enough to discourage me or took away my interest in knowing what would happen next in the story.

I finished it in PS4, Vita and I also got a copy on Steam. And I'm not sick yet. Not even close to be.

Friends. Family, Hope. Find all of these things in the game and disregard the real-life counterparts. Withdraw from all social events involving your friends and family. Procrastinate even more skilfully and deftly with this charming and deceptively strategic RPG. And, if you're a student like me, disappoint your parents even further by spending an embarrassingly large amount of time before the screen, watching little animals violently flog one another to death.
Because my goodness is this game glorious.

This game has it all : storyline engineered to make you cry, beautiful watercolour artwork, simple yet strategic gameplay, treasure hunting, side quests, crafting, levelling up (with the possibility of grinding if you're into that), hauntingly heartbreaking music and sexy rats in finery and merpeople (again if you're into that). The world and gameplay are utterly absorbing, such that 7pm quickly becomes 10pm and you give up on doing your essay and instead consign yourself to playing for another couple of hours because it's already late and you're kinda tired and what can you do.

reviewText:
Child of Light is one of the most beautiful games in the world.

There's no doubt that the game is mostly story driven, but it's also wonderful in every other aspect. Sure, there's a horrible third-party DRM involved (Uplay), but that shouldn't stop you from buying this game. Anyone who skipped buying it for that reason, or for any reason at all, is missing out.

Boasting exquisite art that amazes the eyes down to the finest detail, playing Child of Light is akin to walking through a picture book. From Aurora's intricate character model to the resplendent backdrops present throughout the world of Lemuria, the game never ceases to impress with its visual glory. Moreover, the ability to fly is granted to the player very early on, allowing you to explore Lemuria as you wish.

Battle in Child of Light is largely similar to typical turn based systems in other games, though there are still some twists that make it unique and perhaps, slightly difficult. Good timing of moves in particular is extremely important to triumph over the various monsters that you will encounter during your journey.

Multiplayer isn't a totally fleshed out feature of the game, but it's possible. During battle, a second player may assist you by controlling Aurora's companion, Igniculus, to slow or stun single targets. This allows you to focus on planning and executing your moves rather than having to bother with micromanagement simultaneously. It's perfectly possible to handle both tasks on your own if playing by yourself, however.

Child of Light's soundtrack was composed by Cœur de pirate (Béatrice Martin), a tremendously talented singer/songwriter. I've personally purchased the soundtrack (which is available on her website) for the sole reason that it was a pleasure to listen to.

Naturally, this game's winning asset is its impeccable story - one that's heartbreaking and heartwarming at the same time, albeit easy to follow and understand. Saying any more would simply ruin the serenity of its plot, so I'll leave it to you to find out for yourself!

reviewText:
I love turn based RPG's and Child of Light delivers a satisfying system encouraging strategy and diligence. It's simple, but as the plot progresses you need to employ new strategies and be smarter to keep up with new enemy variants. Child of Light is addicting and entices exploration. It's not far into the game that you gain a new power to roam around with which makes the game much more enjoyable and opens up the 2D map extensively to reveal a much larger world than you realized. Playing alone is fun in itself, but one of my favorite features in Child of Light is the cooperative mechanic that allows for another person to join in to help explore and fight through use of the mouse. Cooperative play adds a whole new element of teamwork as your partner can use the mouse to heal the party or slow enemies while you plan the next move.

The story and presentation of Child of Light is charmingly reminiscent of a classic Disney movie. The journey of Princess Aurora as she finds her way through a magical woods to find a way to save her father, while not breaking ground in storytelling, has that classic fairytale vibe that harkens the mind to more innocent and simple times. As you journey through the woods you'll come across several companions to join your party. While the cast of characters is diverse and their interactions amusing, you'll find yourself using only a couple through the length of the game--bringing an additional one or two out to deal with certain enemy types. This didn't really bother me, but it's to be expected when you have this many characters in your party in such a short game.

I suppose that's my only gripe with Child of Light--it felt short, but that may be because a friend and I beat it in the length of a day. I got it on sale and don't regret what I payed, but I can't help but feel thankful I didn't pay full price. Regardless, I had a blast exploring and fighting bosses with my friend. If you like RPG's with turn-based battle mechanics or a story that harkens back to the classic Disney Princess tales of yore, then you will enjoy Child of Light.

reviewText:
Talk about a beautiful and engaging game. Child of Light is an RPG from Ubisoft Montreal. Let’s get rocking.

The Good

Firstly, the thing that struck me the most about this game is the art. The artwork is beautiful in every sense of the word. It has a distinctive, watercolor style and it works splendidly with the premise of the game. You’ll really feel like you’re playing through a storybook and it is a wonderful experience.

The story of the game is pretty good and it is filled with interesting characters (and enemies). The game world itself is a great canvas on which the story is able to unfold. It’s imaginative, original, and refreshing.

There’s a good variety of enemy types for you to take on during the course of the game. There’s more than enough to keep you interested in combat.

The combat system itself is very old school. It’s set on a timer, and you’ll need to time your character’s attacks if you don’t want to get interrupted and have to take a penalty on your timer.

The Bad

As far as RPGs go, I typically go in expecting to have at least a good handful of items to equip my character/party with. While CoL does have some items, it is quite lacking on the changeable weapons front.

The Meh

Even if you get this one through Steam, you’ll be having to play it through Uplay.

Verdict: Yea

Child of Light is a solid RPG and a worthwhile addition to any collection (and that is just for the artwork alone). You can find it in the Steam Store and with the Halloween Sale (most likely) just around the corner, you should keep an eye out for this one. As always, thanks for reading.

reviewText:
This game is simply beautiful - from the hand-drawn graphics to the soothing background music. The battle music is epic and reminiscent of Final Fantasy VII. The turn-based combat is nicely unique with the option of using your little glow-worm friend to slow down opponents and heal allies, giving you the chance to get that all important potion or cast in before you're anhilated. Combat is not your usual one-shot-as-you-go, and I admit a couple of the boss fights have taken me a couple of attempts. There is also a nice option to switch out your allies mid-fight to give you the upper edge. Game is not quick to play - the story unwinds slowly as you meet new characters. I've been playing for about 2.5 hours and have only just reached chapter 4/10. The skill/talent tree is also reminiscent of the Final Fantasy games. The puzzles are interesting to complete.

As a bonus, if you're playing this single-player, you also get to control your little friend too, which can be a bit tricky to manage both to begin with, but you soon get the hang of it.

The only downfall I found was the jumping - until you recieve the ability to fly, the jumps are very tight and can be difficult to make with a controller as I couldn't quite get the right diagonal key-press. I found myself putting down the controller and using the directional arrows on my keyboard to complete the jumps - much easier. This, obviously, is no longer an issue once you gain flying.

Overall I give this game 10/10. It's fun, quirky, engaging, and not over-simplified. And guys - don't dismiss this game as being girly. Give it a try, you never know you might like it!

reviewText: Child of Light is a remarkable adventure. Once I accepted the sadness that is so intertwined with every element, I grew so much closer to Child of Light. It's easy to heap praise on the combat because it's so engaging, and it's certainly a high point in this adventure. That's not what makes Child of Light stand out, though. Rather, it's how confident it is in its own feelings of woe. There are so few games willing to explore that dull ache that I became mesmerized by Aurora's journey, even when I needed to step away from her plight while I regained my composure. Child of Light is a wonderfully realized, somber adventure, and I couldn't be happier that such a game exists.\n\nIgnore the Uplay naysayers; it really doesn't change anything.

reviewText:
Child of Light is one of the best games I've played in 2014. Its art and soundtrack work harmoniously and smoothly, you can spend HOURS playing without getting tired. Unlike AAA titles, CoL has no explosions, blood, violence - that kind of action. At the same time, it finds a balance where there will be a game that you won't sleep because of the lack of action. Even more if you are familiar with turn-based RPGs.

The rhyming story is well constructed and developed by charismatic characters with unique characteristics. Some details about the game interface has bothered me (like not being able to organize my party) but it weren't enough to discourage me or took away my interest in knowing what would happen next in the story.

I finished it in PS4, Vita and I also got a copy on Steam. And I'm not sick yet. Not even close to be.

reviewText:
Warning: Indepth review

Visuals
-Gorgeous watercolor artstyle
-Charming/cute fairytale-like character designs
-Extremely beautiful and detailed environments and scenery aided by the artstyle
-High attention to detail for character/skill animations. E.g, main character fumbles around a lot while wielding/using her sword because it is practically the same size as her

Audio
-Eargasmic fully orchestrated soundtracks
-Music styles range from lighthearted disneylike bgm to intense, adrenaline pumping musical scores to sombre, lonely, melancholic pieces
-Soundtracks that play during normal monster battles are so epic that they feel more like final boss battles instead
-Much effort and detail put into sound effects for every little thing. E.g., sound of barefeet stepping on wet rock as your character moves around a dark forest, or the metal tinkering sound of the crown when it hits the floor

Story
-Straight out of a fairytale, but with a slightly dark and gloomy atmosphere replacing the usual happy, uplifting mood found in these type of stories
-Some nice plot twists and turn of events that match well with the sorrowful mood of the story, but otherwise, fairly straight forward like most fairytales
-despite the generally sombre feeling of the story, still heartwarming at times
-At its core, a coming-of-age story. People looking for something with an intricate and deep plot will be disappointed

Characters
-With the plot being reminiscent of a disney movie, likewise the characters also follow suit (talking animals/ mythological creatures)
-Charming/cute characters that compliment each other well due to their distinctive personalities and character traits
-Main character (Aurora)  is an incredibly cute and sweet, but brave little girl. (Very likeable protagonist)

Dialogue
-Everything is spoken in rhymes; adds to the cuteness/fairytaleness of the story, but may become annoying for some people as the game progresses

Gameplay
-Old school turn based combat with several added twists
-Order of turns in combat dictated by a timeline mechanic, which is further influenced by an interruption mechanic when characters are attacked during the 'casting' part of the timeline
-Timeline/interruption/cursor mechanic help add to the tension/unpredictability of fights and fosters strategic elements unique to these mechanics (e.g, knowing when it is worth using weak, but fast speed attacks to interrupt enemies VS straight brute force killing the monsters with strong but long cast time spells)
-However, at its heart, it is still turn based battle, so it will not appeal to all people despite the previously mentioned mechanics that speed up the flow of battle

Recommend to everyone but the most diehard haters of turn-based battle.

Oh, and theres Uplay. ♥♥♥♥ Uplay.

But seriously though, it's worth the hassel of installing and signing up for Uplay to experience this game. Cheers~
