So I finally got this game working... As everyone has said below, dealing with the uplay is a nightmare.  Here's what worked for me:

1.) go into steam and retrieve the product key - don't install game
2.) shutdown steam completely
3.) go to uplay.ubi.com and download the uplay client from their website.
4.) install the uplay client you downloaded
5.) let it do it's updates
6.) go to activate product and enter the key you copied from steam
7.) once it shows up in the uplay library relaunch steam
8.) install game from steam
9.) run from steam

I'm clicking yes for recommend, the game is great so far and it shouldn't suffer just because of the software it got packaged with.

reviewText: Beautiful game with music to match.  It's got a battle system that's similar to the JRPG Grandia series, which is a lot of fun.  Battles have a timeline where characters and enemies have to wait until it's their turn and actions take differing amounts of time to perform. Strategy gets enhanced by buffs/debuffs, counters, and the ability to swap characters instantly on your turn.\n\nI was able to get through on Expert fairly easily without any time spent grinding for levels, although I didn't avoid any enemies as I enjoyed the battle system too much.  Leveling up grants you skill points which you can spend on one of 3 branches of the skill tree.

It's a very light hearted adventure with amusing characters, and some banter between our two main heroes. Also what an appropriate time to buy this as it does give off a very soothing autumn-esque feel. But I'm not gonna lie some of the enemies are just outright daunting. I was pretty startled when one of them screamed and leaped at me when I least expected it.

Lets talk about the visuals for a second because this game is gorgeous. The animation is baby skin smooth and  heavily sprite based, as in some enemies have each limb seperatly animated but lets not get too off track here. The fact that this game was and RPG kinda turned me off on it and yeah it's simple. But DAMN does it get intense. also battles are a bit interactive which gives them a bit of flare (literally) and keeps you from getting disinterested.

Its not fully voice acted which I find a bit of a shame because I like to voice my characters as I play my RPG's. And I ain't no little girl, I'm a man... teenager... male.

But with that My final verdict so far is
9.5 out of 10

With my ownly gripe being that its not fully voice acted but since I'm not even close to being half-way through the game,  that might change
the 9.5 is also for the poor souls who can't play this this beautiful game without bad framerate or even start it up because of Uplay
And that hair... Too much hair...

-Time for an update-

After completing the game I was a bit shocked as people weren't kidding. The game is SHORT. And I'm fine with that, but it seemed a bit TOO short for an RPG. This will affect my final grade for it though, but not by much. There were some nice twists, but nearing the end the story began to seem a bit rushed and I would have liked a *SPOILERS PROBABLY* bit more build up to the epic final boss of the game. Maybe one little mini-dungeon to go through to prepare a little more. (not that I was underprepared or anything) But it just all happended so fast and it killed a bit of the climactic feeling. But I still don't regret my purchase because my grade has only changed to:

9.0 outta 10 - Would play again.

reviewText: Child of Light is a 10-15 hour game that incorporates elements of turn-based rpgs and platforming in order to weave a tale of fantasy and lost kingdoms.  Immediately striking is the use of water-color inspired backdrops and lighting effects. Each new area and set piece within the game was designed with the same level of care and detail that one would expect from traditional art. The soundtrack, as well as the tone of the storyline, invokes a strange sense of nostalgia for fairy tales and children’s books. Without divulging any spoilers, there are elements of the storyline that mirror tales by Hans Christian Andersen and the Brothers Grimm. And much like these authors tales there lays a certain air of darkness and sadness to the story narrative of Child of Light. Despite this, I consider the game to be suitable for kids.\n\nThe gameplay element was both familiar and simplistic, however the use of the right analog stick to assist in puzzle solving added a bit of flavor and variety to the platforming. Battles were fought using a turn-based system, with the ability to slow or speed up a character or enemy along in the timeline. This allowed for interesting on-the-fly" decisions that made the combat fun and allowed for a bit of strategy to be incorporated. XP is awarded after winning battles which can be used to develop a skill tree. Each character the player encounters in the game will have various "specialty" skills

reviewText:
I heard so many wonderful reviews of Child of Light, that I started to be sceptical, and I wanted to know if they were truly as good as everyone said. As I have been so severely let down by triple A titles lately, this seemed like a much needed break.

I will sum up everything below in this sentence: Child of Light is the sumation of the genre of RPGs, and an experience I find *essential* to any gamers repitoire.

This game started out slow, as many RPGs do, but I was swiftly entranced in what was going on, and suddenly I was 10 hours in and micromanaging my inventory as I panicked about the fact that it was suddenly 5am on a work day. As your party grows, alongside your powers, you may have difficulty deciding who to power up, who to play up, and who to bench, I know I did. I've just prior to writing this discovered a new game plus mode, which I will be devoting this next weekend to. Now I want to break down the game into parts.

Graphics 5/5
Now I know this game had such a different style of graphics, but I have to say, it so acurately represents the style it brings, I can't not love it. The fact that I could actually feel accurate depth with the style, and on multiple occasions, that came into play.

Story 5/5
Yes, it has some of the basics of any RPG, good vs. evil, light vs. dark, and family matters. However, it plays it so well, and makes you care so much, that you get excited and upset, and as someone who not often pines for anything less than a hurt puppy, this is a major deal.

Gameplay 3/5
Now, don't get me wrong, I loved the gameplay. The combat in this game is one of my favorite features, with how smooth and dynamic it is, yet while being so simple. The only thing is, I know that I like, but I can see where others wouldn't. If you are not a traditional RPGer, and especially level grinder, you may have some rough spots.

Overall score 9.1/10
While exceedingly beautiful and excelling at exactly what it is, the game has a few faults for those not used to the idea of level grinding, and your finger might cramp a bit from using your firefly companion. However, I would reccomend this game to anyone willing to hear me out.

reviewText:
(In short) If you love games with female protagonists who are adorable and kickass with a sword and spells, and a fairytale type of story, having the characters talk in rhyme, and have an aesthetic eye for watercolor rendered games, you should buy Child of Light.



(For all reasons to like and dislike the game, read on.)



The Pros

The Soundtrack If you guys think that the artwork and cute story is what attracted so many people to love this game, its not. Its mainly the soundtrack. If you look at the videos of the soundtracks on youtube, they are flooded with positive comments. Everyone loves the songs and ugh just the love for this game is amazing haha. Once you finish the game, listen to the soundtrack and just cry, again.

The Artwork of the game was amazing. It was so beautiful, you were literally flying around in a giant painting. Games rendered in a watercolor style is so beautiful in my opinion, I couldn't help but to squeal at every new map that I encountered haha. xD One can tell that a TON of effort went into the making of this game. Just from looking at the backgrounds which at first glance, don't seem like much but to anyone interested in art. The lighting and coloring of everything blends together so well and its just so UNF.



The +/- of the game. (depends on perspective)

Uplay/Ubisoft (The biggest concern I had while I was contemplating buying this game..) I guess since Uplay is mentioned on here(in the cons section) I might as well talk about the benefits about Uplay, unlike those Uplay ragers from the reviews of the game earlier in the year mentioned, Uplay isn't bad at all. (Biased opinion because I faced no problems from it but..) Uplay actually gives you these Uplay coin token things as you play the game, and with those coins, you can buy stuff. So for all of those DLC's that you've been wanting, half of them are on Uplay. You can purchase (with Uplay coins) and download backgrounds and stuff. Of course the soundtrack to support the artist is on Steam, and that one DLC that includes a new party member is also on steam. If anything really the DLC's on steam offer you 2 outfit changes and a new party member, because sure the others offers extra occuli, but you find them randomly in the game anyways. (Sometimes, even monsters drop them), so Uplay isn't all that bad, and the DLC's that Steam offers arent bad either. Half of those DLC's that you guys are complaining and bichin' about, are on Uplay. (more stuff on Uplay is at the bottom of the review.)

The Price (?) Some people complained about the length of the game, but I thought that the game length matched the price, if anything I think that the price is just right. (The extreme fans of CoL can of course argue with me on this) Many people complained about the length of the game not matching of the price or the worth of the game, but that shouldn't be an issue, because one can just replay the game, in a harder mode if you found the game too short or too easy. I'm going to do that. (I played on Casual, like the scared little noob gamer I am) I heard that it provides more challenges, (and many deaths haha.)

The 3D on 2D The only thing that I disliked was that Aurora was 3D. Dispite the background being in 2D with with different layers in the background moving to add a bit of deph into the otherwise flat looking background, the main characters looking 3D looked a bit out of place in my opinion. I just would have preferred for the few characters (including Aurora) to be in 2D along with the bg, but I knew that would have been hard work since Aurora doesen't sit still, she flies around so I understand that its just easier for her and the few other characters to be 3D. It just bothered my eye while playing the game.

The Rhyme If you don't like for all of the characters to talk in rhyme (It is slant rhyme I believe) this game will be annoying for you. If you can tolerate it and not give the game a negative review just because they talk in rhyme, or because of Ubisoft, thank you. The rhyme isn't for everyone and thats okay. Scurry along somewhere else, don't just bash the rhyme.

The Style Of The Story The story itself is also very Disney like. Its basically a fairytale. Its not hard to follow at all, I think that because of the way that the game was made that it can appeal to all ages besides the very young children because they may not understand the full story. Such as Aurora's flashes of vision that the fountains granted her of what the fk was going on at home. Some people complained about there being no background information on the game. I think that the game gave all of the information that one needed to know at the beginning. And the rest of the surprises that the game throws at the player is just y'know cut scenes that are supposed to add problems and drama into the story to make it interesting.. If you pay attention to whats going on, its not difficult at all to follow.

The Fights Oh the fights there were so many complains about it. I didn't like it. It was a first for me for this type of fighting system where it was turn based. It was not difficult in terms of strategy. With different skills/abilities/spells, and your firefly friend Sir Igniculus, you can make it so that you attack more than said turn. I didn't mind it. Sure the battles were always the same. Figure out weaknesses of the enemy and kill them. You have many friends who you can switch out in the midst of the battle, whom all have different abilities and specialties which can make it somewhat more interesting than just having Aurora slash at enemies with her sword, yes? It also kept the game balanced, I mean if you were able to have like all 5 of your allies (if even 5) out to attack like 3 enemies at max of course the game'd be too easy. It limited the game in the fighting system to make it so that the battles are worth thinking about. Like do you take out a fellow damage dealer for a support character who can heal/buff you? There were not many possibilities but did require me to think a bit as I played. BUT if its strategy that you are looking for my friend, there is not much to this game in terms of the battles. I recommend setting the game to hardcore mode or something. There are also only like 3 songs that play depending on the battle. Its the same for when just grinding mobs (to level up, and its all optional too, I mean. You should.. level up to even have a chance at defeating the boss..) the only times that I've noticed the soundtrack change was in big boss fights which you will encounter as the story progresses.



The Cons.

Problems with the Game I had little to no problems with it. I've read a lot of the other reviews and heard others bichin' about how because of UPlay that they don't recommend it... But honestly I thought that Uplay wasn't a problem. If anything those problems with Uplay being down and stuff, I think that those problems are fixed now because in the few days that I've played Child of Light and finished it, I had never had Uplay exiting the game for me, or for that manner, and problems from or dealing with Uplay. My game was never disrupted. The worst that it got was the second to half of second of lag that went away immediatley while I flew around in the map. Or of how sometimes in some of the battles, Aurora had no hair. It didn't bother me that much because to be honest, it was only one battle out of how many now? reviewText:
Wow, just beat this amazing game last night and it moved me so much as a person that I owe UbiArt a review.

Right out of gate, I want to comment on Uplay. This game (as with other ubisoft games) requires the installation of Uplay, which is a game launcher that runs outside of steam. Every time you play it does make you log in to Uplay, and while some view this as the biggest annoyance in the world, I honestly don't mind Uplay and barely notice it anymore. Now that I have this covered I will break down the rest of the game in readable chunks.

Menu Interface - 9 - I played the game with a controller pad, and found everything accessible, my only minor complaint is in the crafting screen where it can get frustrating to remove gems.

Open World Interface - 10 - Playing outside of combat is a thing of beautiful and fluid experience, not once did I feel like Aurora or Igneous was not an extension of myself. Exploration and loot gathering is well paced, and still offers a challenge for those completionists out there. Puzzles and open world dangers offer complexity and can require fluid control, but did not frustrate me or deter my desire to explore. Engaging combat is controllable, and the few times I was ambushed by a well placed enemy it was honestly fun.

Combat Interface - 9 - Turn based combat has a nostalgic grab for me personally, and I can say Child of Light does it right. The default combat speed gradually introduces you to the flow of combat, and once you feel you have it locked down you can up the speed for a more seamless experience with quicker progression. My only wish is that I could have a third party member on the board during combat. UbiArt made up for this by allowing on the fly member switching, but I still felt like combat would have been more dynamic with a third member on the board, that said the use of Igneous as support was executed beautifully.

Story - 8 - The story of Aurora is enticing and tugged at my heart strings. Her journey through the fantastical world Lumaria expresses personal growth and paints vivid a picture of the pain involved with growing up. While Aurora’s story felt deep and heartfelt, I found myself wanting more depth behind the support characters in addition to their small side quests.

Visuals - 10 - I took so many screenshots during my first playthrough I lost count. This game is a testament to how great side scrolling (semi 3D) games can look. Countless times I found myself saying how great the game looked out loud to myself, my girlfriend, or through social media.

Audio - 9 - Visuals are important and most gamers put an emphasis on “graphics” as their point of reference to game quality. I am of the opinion that visuals and audio work hand in hand, and Child of Light uses its music to create an immersive atmosphere that compliments its visuals like a twin sibling. My only gripe is that some of the sound effects can get loud and in a few instances became slightly irritating to the point where I turned down the volume. Aside from this small pet peeve, I could not possibly express how touching and appropriate the music is, and has found a place in my playlists.

I could not be happier with my purchase of this game. I was excited to play it months ago, and it has surpassed every expectation I had. Any fan of RPG’s, music, art, and well told stories will enjoy what Child of light brings to the table. I hope this review helps any who are on the fence decide to give this game a shot, you will not be disappointed.

reviewText:
An immersive and beautiful game that would always remain as one of my favorites. With its impeccable artwork and illustrious plot/dialogue, Child of Light never fails to succeed in drawing me deeper into the world of Lemuria.

Gameplay was interesting, simple and reminds one of the old school turn based Final Fantasy battle style. Although only 2 characters can be used at any one time, the mechanics are simple and really easy to understand.

Furthermore, battles are surprisingly just as lively and beautiful as the game. Characters also level easily and there's absolutely no need to grind! (Unless you tend to skip battles actively!)

Character development was done really well, and the repertoire of characters with their lively dialogues truly brings the game to life.

For only $15, this game is honestly quite the steal! I am even willing to pay $30 for this treasure!

Most importantly, the soundtrack is just so beautiful and in synchrony with the plot that as a casual gamer, I really took my time to listen in and enjoy the calming melodies the game has to offer. Definitely getting the entire soundtrack!

Highly recommend this to any casual gamers out there who wants to enjoy 11-13 hours of a beautifully drawn masterpiece and live out your conventional fairytale in Child of Light! C:

P.S. I thought the trailer seemed kinda childish at first but the first hour of gameplay showed me how wrong I am to judge this game so quickly at face value, hope everyone out there enjoys this game! Have not tried the DLCs but will get around to it!

reviewText: A good place to start for anyone new to the rpg genre. The game has wonderful imagery and the atmosphere is set well. The combat system is similar to the active time battle system in older final fantasy games, with a few twists. Also the game has a touch of 2d side scrolling as you explore the world you're in. The game isn't too short, but it is easy, so if you want a challenge with your RPG then stick the difficulty up to expert. Replay value comes in the form of a New Game + mode after you finish, which keeps your skills and Occuli from your save file, in return for harder opponents.\n\nIn short for the price this is a really well made rpg, and if you're curious about the genre and whether you would like this give it a shot. As a major rpg fan, I can definitly recommend this title.

I found it was beautiful to look at, and while flying around the art and environment was wonderful. It felt very much like a children’s storybook and the art style looked hand painted.                Audio        9.5        I really enjoyed the soundtrack to this game. The music here really set the mood at the appropriate moments. The sounds in the game were fitting and often guided/alerted me when I was begrudgingly entering battle.                Replayability        3        While it was a relatively fun game to play, I can’t see myself continuing to maximize my character’s stats/abilities any further, let alone replaying the game again. With a decent story and gameplay, I have no wishes to return to Lemuria.                Overall        7.5        Child of Light set me in a beautiful place called Lemuria. The music added to the tranquil beauty. But the controls felt awkward at times, though didn’t hinder me too much. I want to love the story, but unfortunately I couldn’t get passed the rhyming.

reviewText:
Storyline: 6/10
It's interesting and evokes some feels, but it's not anything that would incite any intense emotions.

Gameplay: 7/10
The combat system is simplistic for those who don't want to think too much, but also quite in-depth for those who want to get down and dirty. Every character has his own niche and are all good in their own rights. They all have their individual skill trees that will increase their stats and unlock new abilities. There are also gems in the game that serve as equipment for your party members, and they can be combined into newer and stronger gems.

Graphics: 7/10
The background is pretty cool, drawn in a free flowing, paint brush style. There's nothing really super flashy or impressive in the characters and animations, but there are also very few eyesores.

Content: 2/10
This is the biggest selling point, or lack thereof. I personally finished the first playthrough of the game in about 15 hours, and this includes a moderate amount of grinding and looting (both can be skipped). The game is too easy; there are autosaves at literally everything you do, enter a door, beat an enemy, open a chest, etc etc. There are no penalties for death, if you can even manage that; one can heal up to full HP/MP at any point in the game with the help of Igniculus and wishes. There's also a new game+ option, but this is farily trivial, as it is easier than the first playthrough. XP gains are boosted, causing all characters to be fairly overleveled have most of the important skills when they are needed. After beating the second playthrough, the game doesn't get any harder, so trying to beat the game a third time will only result in one hitting most enemies along the way. I was pretty hyped to be able to max out all of the characters and gems (which is actually pretty time consuming), only to realize that there's nothing to use my powered up party members on.

Overall, not recommended if you want a long term investment like an in-depth RPG. It was entertaining while it lasted though.

reviewText:
Child of Light is a family-friendly game that is written all in rhyme, designed to be played as 2-players side by side (so parents, maybe this is how you enjoy games with your kids rather than shooing them from the room so you can play Saint's Row - or worse, letting them stay in the room with you and play all your M-rated titles)

At best, CoL is a beautiful combination of painting and poetry, which can teach young players some basic platforming and turn-based RPG elements, with a competent adult actually doing the playing, the little player 2 can enjoy the narrative and do a few things that are much needed, once they are shown the way.

As an adult, playing it by yourself, will you enjoy it as much? Well, probably not, which isn't to say it's a bad game, after all, you will be able to see how much work has gone into making this game, and while it may be simple, well that's all the more credit to it, it's a smart design and it doesn't overcomplicate things.

Just, do not, I repeat, do not, under any circumstances, buy oculi. I bought the entire bundle of them along with all the other micro-transacion DLC, but without really knowing why. I guess it's just something we're used to seeing from AAA game devs, and we've been letting them get away with it. (I bought the game and DLC on sale though, otherwise I wouldn't have had even a passing interest in this based on other peoples' reviews that all gripe about Uplay.)

So what are oculi, then? Well, they are gems, that go into sockets on your weapons and armor, each having a small stat benefit, and they are craftable within 3 tiers. They drop in the game as well, so if you don't buy them, don't worry, you get them included in the game already, and for the price of a couple dollars for 3-4 of them, really, you can't let yourself get ripped off like that. It's not like you have to seek out the hardest difficulty setting, there is a casual mode, and really, that's the only way I think it should be played, so you can enjoy it for what it is, and put the evil Corporate Commander" EA / Ubisoft

reviewText:
Child of Light is a role-playing game from Ubisoft. The game was oficially released on Windows, PS3, PS4, X Box and Wii U, but in July 2014 they released it on PlayStation Vita.
What I really liked in this game is that it has some RPG elements in it, such as leveling-up. Child of light also has an amazing graphics and the storyline written by Jeffrey Yohalem, writer of Assassin's Creed: Brotherhood and Assassin's Creed II.
In this game, you can play as Aurora, the main character, a child stolen from her home, who must bring back the sun, the moon and the stars. She is helped by her playable companion firefly. She also meets several allies along the way, including Rubella, Finn, Norah, Robert, Tristis and etc. With their help she will face her darkest fears.
The game has unique, watercolor-esque world created in Ubisoft's UbiArt Framework engine, therefore it will include a variety of platforming elements and puzzles.
Child of Light is considered as a playable poem. The dialogues rhyme and will unfold the story similar to fairytales.
In my opinion Child of Light is one of the best games of the year and i totally recommend it for y'all indie game lovers. Enjoy!

So here is the thing - if you like Uplay, or aren't annoyed by having to use another steam-like client in addition to steam every single time you want to play this game - consider my review a thumbs up and move on to the second portion of my review.

The following reasons for hating Uplay are my reasons for giving this a thumbs down (this is ubisoft developed)

1. Steam already exists.
2. Uplay is chewing up more than 0% of my resources.
3. There is no way to bypass Uplay to simply launch Child of Light.
4. Uplay pop-ups.
5. Steam ALREADY EXISTS AND HAS ACHIEVED MARKET SATURATION.

Please - if any part of Ubisoft is reading this, add it to the pile, we hate Uplay! We hate uplay, even the people who love your games (and I really enjoyed what I played of child of light!) hate uplay. Stop foisting it on people in an attempt to replicate valve - you will never replicate valve, as evidence by the fact that I am writing this review on steam, and so have many others.


The game itself

Not without its flaws, the rhyming gets a bit repetitive, and the combat feels shallow in certain ways (repetitive abilities, recycled enemy art) yet is satisfying and the story and environment are delightful. I really enjoyed how it fused a fairy tale style with JRPG mechanics and was intrigued to see how it concluded. If you enjoy JRPGs, and like what you've seen from the screenshots and video I would hazard a purchase, just make sure you have an hour set aside to try it out in case you need a refund.

I honestly would have happily finished this game, but every single time I went to play it, Uplay functioned as some sort of harassing butler that kept jabbering at me about sales and uplay points or some such nonsense. I'd give the games a thumbs up - but the shrieking visage of Uplay  is now linked to it via pavlovian response, so I give the two of them a thumbs down. reviewText: I had heard pretty good things about Child of Light.  It looked pretty cool so I thought I'd give it a shot.  Well, the background artwork is quite nice, for sure, but the design and animation of the characters feels a bit sloppy (though I do like the flowing hair).  Besides that, I don't have much to complain about what it looks like.  The game itself, however, is not very interesting.  Even the puzzles are simple and somewhat repetitive, involving lighting up different objects in a pattern.  While flying around and collecting treasure and potions I forget to use can be mildly entertaining, the battles are a disappointment.  It works kind of like turn based strategy of sorts, where you can use your glowing firefly to slow down the opponents.  In other words, battles are about timing and luck.  Even though you get different characters and can work strategies out with the different styles, the main problem is that it is boring.  It is the same type of battle over and over and over again.  Fly around, fight new monsters, fly around, fight more monsters.  Also, I would have liked it if at least three characters could be placed in the battle at a time like the enemies are.  I want to like the game, but I really just can’t.  The fights are pretty long and simply a lot of repetition of trying to blast enemies with your most powerful spell while attempting to avoid becoming paralyzed.  It can take forever.  Lastly, this is more of a personal preference, but I did not like the dialog between characters that shows up quite often.  It does not add to the plot and the poetry feels hastily thrown together to find something, anything that rhymes.  It gets annoying, especially when a new character joins the team and then every single other character must introduce themselves to that one.  Overall, I think the game could have been much better if there were a few tweaks made to it, but as it stands, I’m not very impressed.  Also, Uplay is a hassle.

Even though you get different characters and can work strategies out with the different styles, the main problem is that it is boring.  It is the same type of battle over and over and over again.  Fly around, fight new monsters, fly around, fight more monsters.  Also, I would have liked it if at least three characters could be placed in the battle at a time like the enemies are.  I want to like the game, but I really just can’t.  The fights are pretty long and simply a lot of repetition of trying to blast enemies with your most powerful spell while attempting to avoid becoming paralyzed.  It can take forever.  Lastly, this is more of a personal preference, but I did not like the dialog between characters that shows up quite often.  It does not add to the plot and the poetry feels hastily thrown together to find something, anything that rhymes.  It gets annoying, especially when a new character joins the team and then every single other character must introduce themselves to that one.  Overall, I think the game could have been much better if there were a few tweaks made to it, but as it stands, I’m not very impressed.  Also, Uplay is a hassle.

reviewText: DISSAPOINTING. Excuse the caps, but I thought it might ask for a bit of attention amongst the floods of positive reviews. The combat in this game is extremely repetitious, and very limited in terms of play styles. Despite having many characters available, you are only able to fight with two at any given time. The skills and simple trees are relatively uninspired, or should I say, extremely inspired by what has frequently been used in past RPG's. The visuals -while aesthetically o.k- really don't go far enough considering the financial backing of ubisoft. Using items/healing/skilling up is tedious with a non-user friendly one at a time character view, and the whole craft your own gems (which add stats/buffs) is equally as limited. You end up making the same ~5 gems over and over again but in higher concentrations (and stat bonuses). This game will pleasantly waste some of your hours, but it is probably not worth the asking price. That being said, it may be a more enjoyable game for a very young audience. I'm 24.

reviewText:
After playing it for a couple of hours more I cannot recommend Child of Light. It's very dull gameplay and almost cringeworthy dedication to making up rhymes for every single line of dialogue, which not only breaks the immersion but also makes me roll my eyes way too hard, makes it a very mediacore experience.

I could ignore the terrible idea of rhyming if the gameplay made up for it, but neither the exploration of the world, which is reduced to some simple puzzles and really dodgy 'platforming' (more like dodging obstacles in air really), nor the RPG-esque fighting really qualify this game as 'fun'.

The fights drag on for longer than necessary and even the 'weaknesses' become meaningless: you attack a fire looking monster so you equip oculi for water attack and fire defence. But you realize when you enter a fight that it also has an earth and air buddy.
Also the game plain lies to you - defending is supposed to prevent you from being interrupted the game says, and then happily introduces enemies who ignore defence and knock you back despite defending. At the same time the AI is pretty dumb, often not 'finishing off' characters with low health and instead going for the full health party member, which means you can't really leave low HP people as decoy either.

So the gameplay is dull, how about the story?

The characters are varied sure but it's easy to see more effort went into finding rhymes than into actually making the characters memorable. I can berely say anything about the people in my party and it seems like they talk a lot - yet except for terrible rhymes the dialogues contain little to none information. It takes a lot of talent to convey a story through rhymes and the writer here just plain failed in most cases.

Also you can tell how desperate he or she was for rhyming when a child uses words like 'commerce'. Aurora uses words that don't fit into child's mouth. So yes, rhymes make the game lose the immersion factor.

Overall it's a pretty looking experiment of a game that failed in delivering whatever it was they tried to do.

reviewText:
Child of Light was everything I was hoping it to be, it was immersive, it was gorgeous, and above all, it had a phenomenal soundtrack.

Child of Light tries something fun with it storytelling by having the characters rhyme whenever they talk. It's not for everyone but I was rather fond of it. It made the game feel like a fairy tale come alive.

The exploration of the world is fun and exciting, the first level of the game sets you up for what to expect throughout the rest of the world, and I have to say, it's never disappointing. Treasure hunting rarely feels like a chore and the ways to obtain certain treasure feels refreshing and uncomplicated.

In terms of combat Child of Light takes a page from the classic rpg format of turn based fighting and adds several implements. This makes the turn based fighting immersive and exciting and with the allies you come across you will find many unique and interesting ways to topple the competition. There is also a gearing system involving gem stones, I've barely scratched the surface on this and I gotta say, the upgrades you choose through this system really play a part in combat.

My only real gripe with child of light is how short the game feels. When the game comes to the end you feel like you could've used more time to grind your allies and discovered more quests/treasure. I guess I'll check out the dlc and story plus and see if that doesn't change my mind.

Child of Light is a must play for RPG and fantasy enthusiasts.

reviewText:
Simply Epic. The first thing you'll notice is the music, oh god, words can't even describe how beatiful the music is, really only the violin will make your skin shiver. And that end credits music. The gameplay is also very fun and it's battle system shares the ATB(Active Time Battle) system in numerous Final Fantasy games, but adds it's own special touch keeping the things fresh on every enemy encounter. In terms of difficulty, if you want somewhat of a reasonable challenge go on Hard, but even Normal keeps you on your toes.

The level design is absolutely gorgeous and the scenarios are even more breath-taking, so much that you can download wallpaper versions on Uplay via Rewards. The only downside on this game is the linear story, don't get me wrong it's very good but lacks of epic twists that keeps a story fresh and engaging. In other words, if you truly seek a gorgeous adventure, full with epic hand-drawn scenarios and original and well-developed characters, and games like Final Fantasy, don't hesitate to buy this masterpiece and fall into the world of Lemuria, you will not regret it, or if you prefer playing a role against the Russians in a half-♥♥♥♥♥ campaign, be my guest.

9/10

reviewText:
Child of Light is a fairy tale about Aurora, the princess of Austria (?). Falled into a fantasy world, she lives an adventure to save her family and her people, and she also discovers her own marvellous destiny.

The visual design reminds of old child book illustrations; it is beautiful, although sometimes silly and mushy (...why girls' hair are always horizontal, moved by an omnipresent wind lol?) ...the story and the character design (thanks to the quests she takes, Aurora meets many original characters) are well conceived, also some unexpected plot twists are present.
Rpg features are reduced to quests and characters modification via trees of abilities, but do not expect visible customization or complex character study: you may choose random evolutions and they will equally functions.
The turn-based combat system with the action timeline is generally easy, but also smart and it requires a good amount of reasoning and resources management.

A positive note about the music, that will remain in your mind.

Another curios aspect of the game are the dialogues and narration... all of them are in rhymes. That's cute but... at least in the italian version, no metrics are provided by the authors; for this reason, some sentences just sound contrived and stupid. Such as... not fairy/inspiring characters, but childish idiots who force their own speaking to put rhymes in it at any cost.
The idea is cool Ubisoft, but if this is the goal... next time, please hire an experienced poet!

vote 7.5/10

reviewText:
I finished this game and that's really saying something.  I usually lose interest eventually and don't finish.  This one has that perfect balance to where it kept me entertained and interested enough to continue playing, but didn't make me dedicate too much as far as time and patience.  I recommend it for gamers like myself who prefer less depth on occasion for the sake of being able to jump in and play it for an hour or two after work.  Here are a few pros and cons because I'm not much of a composer.

+Beautiful artwork
+Fast paced yet turn based combat that's entertaining enough to make you want more
+Lots of secret loot to find
+Crafting is very simple but effective
+Character progression is well-balanced
+Diverse characters with lots of different skills
+Ease of travel
+Shallow story for shallow folks
+Short and sweet
+Reasonably priced, especially at the 60% off discount

-Poetic dialogue is pretty cheesy, but I get it
-Potions are a bit useless unless you're in a dire situation
-Could have used a little more difficulty in combat, just a little

I give it an 8/10, if they ever make a second one, I will insta-buy.

P.S.  I should also say that Uplay is not a big deal in any shape or form.  I see a lot of people freaking out over it, but they're just being dramatic pansies.  In the 24 hours it took me to beat this, I saw the Uplay screen a total of about 60 seconds. It never once interfered with anything at all.  Also, if it prevents piracy, I'm all for it.  Get a job and buy your games, people work hard on them.

reviewText:
Child of Light is a  beautiful  game. The art has a lovely watercolor look that adds to the fairytale feel. The music is really well done, too - evocative, supporting but never overpowering the action. However, the story is short and to reiterate, it is a  fairytale  , so if you want an epic campaign to save the world, this isn't it. This is a story about a child growing up, learning to become a leader, how to deal with loss and betrayal, and how to be everything she needs to be - strong, caring, gentle, noble, and powerful.

One of the strongest points of Child of Light is the combat system - there are about four to six things you have to keep track of simultaneously, and it gets crazy. The real-time turn-based combat was immensely fun - you can only battle with two of your party members at a time, and often the enemy has three combatants that attack at different moments and at different speeds. Learning to control the firefly and shift your party members in and out of the fight in order to combo-stunlock the enemy is a wonderful challenge that really never gets old.

I really enjoyed the diversity of characters here. They come in all shapes and ages and sizes, and all the characters become strong, with their own motivations and stories. In one case, it's a girl being strong for her depressed brother. In another, it's an orphan out for vengeance on the people who killed her parents. There's a mage out to prove himself to his elders. A disgraced warrior out to restore his honor. A boy who wants to win a fair lady's heart. Major points for not sexualizing the female characters, especially as two of them are about 7-10 years old.

You can't customize your characters' weapons/armor. You can change the stones attached (called Oculi in the game) to add different stats, but you have the same weapons throughout the game and there are no shops and there is no currency. The Oculi are pretty strong - there's the usual RPG combining and there are other stat boosts in the game, but overall customization stays relatively simple.

Perhaps the weakest part of the game is the dialogue - I personally liked it most of the time, but I agree with other reviewers that sometimes clarity is sacrificed for the sake of rhyme. If you hate Shakespeare and can't stand poetry, this game is not for you. The rhyming dialogue gives a sometimes immersive, other times jarring feel - when it works, it's hilarious. When it doesn't, it's just plain bad.

tl;dr:
Pros: beautiful art & music, great combat system, short and fairly casual storyline, wonderful cast of characters
Cons: dialogue is hot or cold, game is relatively short, limited customization

reviewText:
I hope ubisoft realize how many people are not buying this game because of uplay ._.
Anyway, Child of Light is amazing. Looking forward to sequels/ more games like this.
Pros: gorgeous and unique art direction (the environmental art is absolutely breathtaking and I'm really into the water colour style), lovely fairytale-ish story telling, I love the rhyming dialogues but apparently a lot find it annoying, lots of enemies and bosses. Cons: it's a bit too short for me (10 chapters). If you only play to get to the end without exploring then maybe around 10 hours, if you spend time exploring everything and finding all the confessions/ coffers/ stardusts then 20 hours? Game gets really easy once you've gotten the hang of it. I'm currently in ng+ but it's not as challenging as I expected. The ending is a bit rushed. Ng+ is pretty neat since it lets you play against harder enemies and keep all your stuff (except stardusts) but I kinda expected more than that. Maybe some extra areas or bosses would be nice.
Overall it's a really special game. If you're into artsy RPG with a poignant, fairytale-ish plot then this is definitely for you. And guys, come on, it is SOOOOO BEAUTIFUL.

reviewText:
Gamplay:

Standard RPG combat with an addition of an interrupt and slow system that is easy to use but would take some time to master. Outside of combat is standard 2D rpg format that works well with the flight mechanics. Animations, espcially Aurora's, are very nice and well done. Each characters has there own skill tree that has some customization, but not very complicated.


Controls:

I used a keyboard & Mouse.  Controls were simple and easy to use. In battle they are simplified to an active battle system which is easy to navigate. Outside of combat is a very simplistic platformer that does not require much precision. To Control your firefly you use your mouse, this is designed for a mouse, it works very well. With all that said, I believe the standard controls would also work very well with a control & the firefly mechanic would work well with the second joystick on all controllers. Overall- Very Good.

Sound:

Beautiful music that fits the mood all the time, and sound effects fit extremly well with all the Spell effects

Graphics:

Atmospheres are beautifully designed, some of them are downright stunning, from dark & scary forests to Lava filled Trees to underwater caves from beginning to end. Not hard to see what ubisoft focused on while creating this game.

Wothey Notes:

The writing is pretty atrocious, the rhymes seemed very forced and weren't thought to hard about, character deveolpment is lack luster as well but you get the basic points . Only really complaint about this 12 hour RPG. Well worth the money, 8.0 out of 10.

reviewText:
First of all this is my first review and english is not my native language so sorry for either gramatical errors or typos and maybe bad format .

TL;DR version

Graphics 10/10       Stunning . Even if they arent to your taste you cant deny how beautifull they are
Sound 8/10             Nice . it folows the game nothing extraordinary nothing annoying
Music 10/10            Stunning . Just hear it
Story 9/10               Nice . Simple fairy tale but that is the beauty of it
Characters 9/10      Nice . Every NPC has flaws , motivation and they are different persons with no stereotypes
Combat 7/10           Good but can be boring fast
Replayability 2/10  Unless you enjoy the game so much ,if you play it once and do all the quests or gather all confessions                                       .                                there is little reason to play it again

Overall 9/10             A piece of art .

Long version

I saw this game when it first came out , and i said oh well lets fly the jolly roger. Then after i finished it , i just went and bought it . My experience was so good and felt those weird thingies called emotions that actually i shed a tear (meaning i had to literally wipe my eyes.. those onion-cutting ninjas). The selling points of this game are the atmosphere and the plot. But i will explain all of it below

Child of Light is tagged as a RPG , but offers you no choices in the plot element. But (and it is a big but) offers character customization (talents and occuli) and the most important thing character development . For me RPGs should be like that. You see as the time passes that Aurora and her companions grow up emotionally and stand up to the task .

AtmosphereThe thing that made me play this game was the atmosphere . Graphics , dialogues , music are all so immersive that after 12 hours of playing i realized it was morning and i should tuck myself in bed and let the game and complete it later.

Graphics arent realistic . Instead they follow a fantasy and are dreamlike , but that doesnt stop them for being stunning and once in a while you stop to enjoy the view .
Music is a nice background which not only doesnt bother you but you like to hear it .. i cant find the words how well the soundtrack accompanies the game.
Dialogues are in verse , meaning they are poems. They are fun , yet you understand the characters and their motivations and you want to help em .  I always like the dialogeus and read them through but at times speaking in verse can be overwhelming .

Before  saying anything about the story i must say that this is a game which a child of 8 years can play . There is no blood , no cursing , a little jump scaring (you can always scout with the firefly) , and a simple plot(thougt simple doesnt mean not beautiful)
Story . You are a princess of Austria and somehow you wake up in the middle of a dark scary forest away from your papa . Also you mist find the moon and the stars and defeat the evil queen umbra. How the hell a little child will do this ? . Of course with the help of the forest lady , Indignicus , and your companions ! each one has his/her own story and motivation and flaws . As the game goes on Aurora will grow up (changing her model) and finally will be an adult. Aurora is not either a warrior or a wizard... she is just a princess ... how you play is up to you. And that is another thing i love about this game.

Playstyle Combat Well things are simple... you see the timebar , you see when everyone is going to take action and how fast they are gonna do it. Every character ( Aurora included) has strenghs and weaknesses , same goes for enemies. You can change chars by swapping them in battle. You dont get punished for changing a character . After a while you can indentify the enemies and know what to do . What should be mentioned is that you can avoid all battles except bosses . Also you can run from them.
Exploring Go see the screenshots . you fly up and high and the wind brushes your hair and you are free. You are almost always airbound (at least i did it) , and everything is within reach either by you or the shiny blue ball.

Overall if you like fairy tales this game is just for you . Even if you dont, i think you can find a place in your heart for Lemuria and Aurora . This game is a piece or art in which you can actually play . the only bad thing i find is that the game is short and has little to no replay value .

Learning to control the firefly and shift your party members in and out of the fight in order to combo-stunlock the enemy is a wonderful challenge that really never gets old.

I really enjoyed the diversity of characters here. They come in all shapes and ages and sizes, and all the characters become strong, with their own motivations and stories. In one case, it's a girl being strong for her depressed brother. In another, it's an orphan out for vengeance on the people who killed her parents. There's a mage out to prove himself to his elders. A disgraced warrior out to restore his honor. A boy who wants to win a fair lady's heart. Major points for not sexualizing the female characters, especially as two of them are about 7-10 years old.

You can't customize your characters' weapons/armor. You can change the stones attached (called Oculi in the game) to add different stats, but you have the same weapons throughout the game and there are no shops and there is no currency. The Oculi are pretty strong - there's the usual RPG combining and there are other stat boosts in the game, but overall customization stays relatively simple.

Perhaps the weakest part of the game is the dialogue - I personally liked it most of the time, but I agree with other reviewers that sometimes clarity is sacrificed for the sake of rhyme. If you hate Shakespeare and can't stand poetry, this game is not for you. The rhyming dialogue gives a sometimes immersive, other times jarring feel - when it works, it's hilarious. When it doesn't, it's just plain bad.

tl;dr:
Pros: beautiful art & music, great combat system, short and fairly casual storyline, wonderful cast of characters
Cons: dialogue is hot or cold, game is relatively short, limited customization

reviewText:
One of the most beautiful games I've seen since Okami on the Playstation 2.  The watercolor environments remind me of the classic artwork found in old fairytale books.  This is more of a casual feel RPG in that, there isn't a need to rush through anything.  Unlike many other RPGs out there where the hero uncovers a plot of world domination by a dastardly villain, Child of Light doesn't have that feeling of impending doom.  Even the music, beautifully orchestrated (and sometimes feel super epic), doesn't have that urgency to get from point A to point B.

The highlight of this game, as many people will tell you, is the combat system.  It's almost a throwback to the active time battles as in Final Fantasy VII.  Where the combat commands seem overly simplistic in the beginning, it gets more complex as the hero levels up.  Timing is everything.  Literally.  In later stages of the game, if one isn't careful, enemies might force the player to constantly be on the defense, which will deplete the store of potions.

The skill up menu also reminds me of the sphere grid a la Final Fantasy X, which was one of my favorite skill up ideas.

All in all, Child of Light is a gorgeous game and definitely worth a playthrough.  I have to thank my friend for gifting this to me as a birthday present.

reviewText:
In terms of story and gameplay, Child of Light is simplistic when compared to most RPGs. The story is nice, but it isn't very deep. Gameplay -- linear, not open -- is roundly functional and the controls are straightforward and highly intuitive even though the menu-driven inventory system may leave a little something to be desired. The battle system is challenging and paced well, but also a touch formulaic (I suppose that's part of the genre; I have never been an enthusiast of turn-based combat, so perhaps I'm not the one to ask about that).

Here the focus was clearly on art, and it paid off. For the price, it is worth getting this game just to see it. The art style, reminiscent of the fairy tale illustrations of Ivan Bilbin, is astounding in imagination and execution. It is *the prettiest* game I have ever seen, as far as that goes.

The only major drawback, annoying enough for me almost not to recommend it to the community, is the godforsaken U-Play DRM from Ubisoft which you must be connected to in order to play. I haven't had any technical problems with it, but I hate invasive DRM of that nature, and this feature seems to be the focus of an awful lot of negative reviews.

I do wish the character dialogue were on par with the game art; clearly it is not. The characters speak in rhyming verse, which adds to the storybook flavor of the game, but it is...well...just not very *good* verse. The dialogue isn't bad, so to speak, it just matches neither the tone nor the quality of the art. They hired serious artists to craft the visuals; if they wanted to use poetry, why wouldn't they hire serious poets? I'm sure lots of great poets out there could use the income.

Overall, though, this is a highly enjoyable gaming experience on the lighter side of the RPG niche, and I'd gladly recommend it to anyone who likes this sort of game flavor. Kudos on the female protagonist, too.

reviewText:
This is one of the most fantastic RPG games I've ever played, and will appeal to both RPG and fans of the JRPG subgenre. With beautiful art work, character development, an immersive story, and humour, people will find themselves lost in this game, and coming to love the main character, perhaps without even realizing it.

In addition to the art work, the battle system is active and rewarding. The game augments the traditonal turn based combat system of the turn based RPG, by creating the 'action bar', which is a time based system that shows how close a character is to being able to act, and the time it will take to complete an action. With the help of Igniculus, a character you meet right at the start of the game, you are able to influence the time it will take enemies to act, and if you're clever, you can interrupt an opponent in the middle of an action, potentially eliminating their ability to do anything throughout a battle. Beware though, because the same weakness applies to you!

So with the fantastic and beautiful story, and simplistic but innovative battle system, the reasons to love this game are many, and even if it's something totally new to a would be buyer, it's something I recommend to everyone.

*** I see a lot of concern over 'Uplay'. This is my only game I use through Uplay (and steam), and I can attest that Uplay isn't hard to use at all. You just start this game via steam, and it'll open through Uplay, it's not annoying at all (though I would add that you want Uplay to remember your log in information if you want to skip the several seconds it takes to log in!).

reviewText:
My wife and I selected this game,
because it offered a co-op campaign.
we loved the art, right from the start,
'til the last monster was slain

-------------------------------------------------------------

I'm reviewing this from the perspective of someone who played as the secondary character while my wife controlled the main player through our 15 hour campaign. Right away I want to applaud the game developers for creating an interesting co-op mechanic. The main player in solo play could just control the secondary role themselves (in fact they still can while another person is plugged in), if you are able to multitask and be effective it pays off to control the sprite character during hard battles. Giving the second player the role of this sprite splits the responsibility so that you don't have to consider as many options during fights, but you will still want to coordinate with the other player to perfect your timing.

It's obvious that this game is uniquely beautiful. Ubisoft came up with a graphics engine that does a great job representing the mythical storied universe that the game takes place in. It's like someone added a physics engine to a children's book watercolor drawing.

The story is told in the form of a poem, which is fun in spirit, but it's not always executed as well as I would have hoped. Otherwise, this is a very solid RPG game with great controller and co-op support.

4/5

reviewText:
Child of Light is a basic 2D adventure through the fantasy land of Lemuria. The princess, Aurora, has died and her papa has lost hope, but with the help of unusual friends there is no time to mope. Aurora battles darkness with friends anew, hoping to see this spiritual adventure through. Magicians, jesters and warriors unite to give the princess one last chance. With each battle won, Aurora makes her advance.

The attractive world of Lemura is rendered with Ubi-Art Framework, but the lack of noteworthy gameplay starts to hurt. Aurora walks or flies across colorful landscapes, stumbling upon treasures and wishes.  Wishes ignite your friendly orb of light and treasures prevent you sleeping with the fishes. The orb stuns foes left and right, but minimal exploration makes the adventure slight.

As you collide with foes, you are thrust into a contrived battle pose. Battles have your friends taking turns to eliminate foes counting three. But the nature of the combat propels enjoyment far out to sea. You jostle to deal elemental damage to susceptible foes, yet constant interrupts keep you on your toes. Once you become a master tactician, bosses turn interrupts into a war of attrition. Some bosses succumb after half an hour, making boss battles repetitive and sour. Combat is tolerable at best - how much you can endure is the true test.

Just as the world lacks excitement, the un-voiced dialogue becomes an indictment. Exactly as this review is written before you, the authors were smitten with rhyming too. Some might think it funny or clever, but it becomes like persistent bad weather. If instead you find this readable, then you’ll likely find the narrative tolerable. Know that there is little that proves enlightening, even as you battle forces most frightening.

If Lemuria is the land we are sent to after death, try to avoid the reaper long after your last breath. If you insist on buying Child of Light to get your arty platforming hit, don’t complain when you discover it’s quite sh…

reviewText:
I’m going to start this review with something that sounds like a slam, though it isn't: I really wanted to love Child of Light. But I didn’t. The reason that I wanted to love it is that from the very first trailer I saw I was enchanted with the graphical styles of the game. This enchantment lasted well into my first playthrough; well past the point where I tired of some game elements I was still excited just to look at each new part of the world Child of Light laid out for me. Every bit of scenery and every sprite looks hand crafted. Winsome characters and sumptuous backgrounds have the look of ink and watercolor art from some gorgeous, moody storybook.

Woods give way to craggy rocks give way to villages revealing one stunning tableau after another. Broken statues stare poignantly. Light shines through stained glass and down from treetops. Giants are visible in the hazy distance… There is beauty, often mixed with melancholy, everywhere—even the fights are suffused with it. The animation of Aurora, the protagonist, is also arresting. The attention paid to the movement of her long hair alone is worthy of mention, as are the animations of her wielding a sword clearly too heavy for her tiny body.

All this is true, but my reaction to the game as a whole is more measured. As mentioned, you play as Aurora, an Austrian princess snatched into a fantasy land where she must lead a struggle against the Queen of Dark whose aim is to steal all natural light in the kingdom. You must recruit allies to your party and complete quests to defeat the Queen. Gameply is a mix of metroidvania, side-scroller environments with puzzles, and quasi-turn-based RPG battles. The integration of these two is interesting: encounters are not random. Monsters are visible in the over-world, and how you interact with them there determines who has the initiative at the beginning of a fight. Another interesting mechanic is that your cursor is a character, a glowing sprite, which moves independently of Aurora and interacts with the environment aiding her progress. Mousing over objects is often counted as the sprite interacting with them, so to some degree you are controlling two characters at once. In general, the over world elements of play are quite easy, though.

Battles involve two party members squaring off against a squad of monsters. The action is driven by a timeline, with each character receiving actions at intervals. This differs from a turn-based system in that the intervals vary significantly between combatants, and can be further manipulated by player actions. Character progression, via a branching maze of unlockable nodes ala FF X, unlock new combat abilities. This simple mechanic generates a variety of interesting fights, though by the end of the game I felt the battles were becoming somewhat monotonous, as often happens with turn-based battle mechanics in simple games.

The game is linier and story-driven. It is here that I had my major complaints. The game creators aimed for a moving coming of age story. (If you have seen it, the Neil Gaiman movie Mirrormask seems to be very much the sort of thing they were aiming for.) But this falls short in a number of ways. One reason is that story scenes are done in a kind of storybook mode with largely static images of the characters acompanied by text. Compared to the rest of the game these sequences are oddly uncharismatic. But a much more major shortcoming is the dialogue itself. The game sets all dialogue in verse. But it seems the writers did not have the skill to make this device actually work for them resulting in bad rhymes and perpetually stilted wording. This verbal lack of poise is oddly at odds with the stunning visual beauty of the game. Perhaps these factors alone are enough to explain my mixed feelings towards the story.

In the final count Child of light still offers a wondrous world to explore and marvel at, it still casts a spell. It just didn’t quite live up to its potential. I was left feeling that if every aspect of the game showed the beauty and polish that the graphics do then Child of Light would be one of the greats. The gorgeous, well-built, casual RPG Child of Light actually is makes me badly wish I could play that game.

reviewText:
It’s an unfortunate thing when one can see the amount of effort that has been put into a game and to come away from it feeling so unsatisfied. Sadly, that is the case with regards to my experience with Child of Light.

Using the UbiArt Framework to create a watercolor world of wonder, Child of Light definitely succeeds in being something lovely to look at; indeed, this is what first drew me to the game. The music is very lovely as well (even touching at times) and adds to the child-like, fairy-tale theming of the game and story. However, it is in this fairy-tale presentation that I believe the game makes its biggest misstep: rhyming.

Bear with me and allow me to elaborate: I know it seems silly that something so innocuous could mar a good game. When first beginning my journey through Lemuria the rhyming came off as quite charming. The spoken narration for the cut-scenes, all written in rhyme, made it feel like a tale being told to a sleepy-eyed child and was not unwelcome in the slightest. As the game wore on, though, and the repeated reading of rhymes continued (some conversations turning bizarre just to tag a rhyme on the end), I found myself completely apathetic towards Aurora and her friends. Every line of dialogue attempts to rhyme with no consistent rhyming scheme throughout, which resulted in all interactions becoming a sort of poetic muddle, preventing any sort of personalities for the characters to shine through past their singular motivations. It’s possible that if each character spoke in a different rhyming scheme then making all dialogue rhyme in some way or another would have been successful; there’s plenty of great literature written entirely in rhyme. As it stands, though, the inconsistent schemes just make the dialogue a chore to read, as one dialogue set will rhyme one way but the next will buck the previous set’s scheme for something else. Near the game’s end, I found myself avoiding side-quests, ignoring potential new party members, and just trying to get to the game’s conclusion so that I could be done with it.

All of which is incredibly disappointing because the game is perfectly functional. The combat is a decent, turn-based affair with a few little tweaks to the long-standing formula that provides additional interest and strategy: nothing to write home about but completely adequate. The same can be said of the Oculi crafting system, which allows you to create additional stat-boosting accessories for your party. These coupled with the aforementioned charming visuals and lovely music could have created a perfectly enjoyable experience but without engaging dialogue to breathe personality into the characters, world, and story, these factors all end up becoming window-dressing to an unfortunately bland experience.

I really wanted to like Child of Light, too, but in the end I don’t feel that I can recommend it. For all its charms it ends up feeling without its own voice or personality, which left me feeling regrettably unfulfilled.

reviewText:
After playing through the entire game and doing most of the side content, I'm still torn. I can't recommend it in good conscience however.

Gameplay: The combat feels like a classic JRPG but with some real-time elements that allow you to control a secondary character (or let someone else use the mouse to do so). This guy can collect healing objects for you, or even slow down your enemies on the timeline which is incredibly useful and adds a new dynamic to trying to interrupt your enemies. Overall I enjoyed the classic combat. My one major gripe is that you only ever can have 2 of your party members out at a time, which seems absurd to me. Especially since your enemies routinely have 3.

Art: You can't say enough about the art style. It's got a brilliant storybook feel that is woven throughout the story as well. The color palette and style is bold and refreshing. Animation leaves a lot to be desired however, as they all look more like paper cutouts hanging from strings.

Story/Writing: This is what ruins the game for me. The story is hopelessly childish and unoriginal, which leaves me wondering what the target audience is. I do realize that this matches the visual style, but there must be ways to achieve a story that is appealing to adults while maintaining the whimsical visuals. Things like Trine 2 or Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons did this wonderfully. Overall the story was sickeningly saccharine. In contrast, Brothers started out extremely fanciful, but quick got dark and serious in it's themes. They're both coming-of-age tales, but Brothers pulled it off in a much more brilliant and emotional way (and without words, yet!). In Child of Light, you'll never care about any of the characters. Speaking of words, I must say a few about the poetry. I feel as if the poetry could have saved the hokey story. However, the poetry was dreadful. The writers made no attempt to compose with any meter or rhythm, but instead stuck stubbornly to their A-B-A-B rhyme scheme regardless of the cadence of the sentences. Shakespeare is rolling in his grave. I love great poetry when it has a solid rhythm and bounce to it (See Penny Arcade's Twisp and Catsby stuff!), but this sounded more like a junior high student writing poetry for the first time. Even the rhymes were a stretch from time to time, and left you gagging or saying oh come on

reviewText:
I would recommend this game to small childrens.
I would not recommend this game to any JRPG fan.

PROS:
-Somehow interresting art if you appreciate it.

CONS:
-Beautifull but ultra depressive music.
-Well written dialogs that I don't care to read. No voiceover? Forget about translating it in a 6th language. Can we just get English voice over?
-Graphics looks like a child's storry book and animations feels like moving pieces of paper. I would rather like colorful anime style graphics.
-Over simplistic everything that will fail to entertain any JRPG fan:
-Simple combat system.
-Characters have only about 3 different moves (if you completed the skill tree).
-There is crafting, but it's only oculis and ultra limitted.
-Gems (they call it oculis), that's the only thing you get in the game and you get tons of it, they are everywhere in the screen. They are annoying.
-No equipment. Really?
-Items: about 10 different items in the game. Health and magic potions, battle elixirs and perma stats boosters.
-No shops, no currency.
-Only 2 party members in combat (at the same time) and a maximum of 3 ennemies.
-Interruptions concept in combat. This is pure annoyance to have to manage this.
-The game is short. Only about 5 hours.

CONCLUSION:
Interresting piece of art, but will fail to entertain JRPG fans. Wait until the price drops below 10$ if you need to try it or just watch someone play on Twich.

reviewText:
Child of Light is a very, very pretty game. I adore the art style, the character designs, and how the environments make it feel like I'm traveling through the pages of a beautifully illustrated fairytale similar to the ones I used to read when I was a child.

The combat in the game was alright, but I found myself wanting to avoid as much as possible as I progressed. I didn't find it all that fun, probably because I never felt like my character was progressing in any significant way. The skill tree wasn't very exciting (I would always forget to assign points because I didn't care), and using oculi in place of traditional equipment was disappointing, especially when having to switch them around frequently depending on what I was fighting.

My biggest complaint with Child of Light, however, was the dialogue. I appreciate what they were trying to do, but I found it very difficult to invest myself in the characters or the story because the rhyming made it hard for me to follow what was going on. It was far too distracting, and eventually I stopped trying to decipher the silliness and button mashed through all the talking.

I wanted to love this game and there are things I do love about it. The soundtrack is wonderful, and obviously it's a joy to look at and explore. I just feel that the most important aspects of this game were the ones that let me down the most.

Also, the Uplay requirement to play is lame.

reviewText:
Child of Light is and all together memorable and refreshing experience that is not to be missed by RPG fans. The beautiful art style and enchanting soundtrack will quickly draw you into a world of fairytales and childhood dreams. The combat clearly takes inspiration from classic RPGs such as Final Fantasy, but combines a traditional Active Timer Battle stystem with the ability to alter and interupt the flow of battle, Battles have a layer of complexity not often seen in standard turn-based combat.

The protagonist may be a mere child, but this game is a fully fledged experience sure to leave an impression!

9/10

reviewText:
This game is a masterpiece. There is so much detail put into the game in regards to art and gameplay. Even in the very beginning, I noticed various hidden locations that can expound on the gameplay or lore as a whole. Although I've only played this for a solid hour, I can assure you that this game is wonderful. I fully recommend it.
The gameplay is very simple from the beginning, and the turn-based battle system is flawless. I enjoy the various strategies I can take in order to attack my opponents faster, defend myself, prevent myself from being interrupted, and etcetera.
The artistic side of the game is perhaps the reason why I first took a look at this game. I don't think I can say much about the artwork other than 'Just check it out. This game is beautiful'.
Finally, the lore. My God, if you love poetry and a beautiful, enthralling, story-telling game, you are probably in heaven now. The story, so far, is amazing. I anticipate great things when I continue to play it.
Child of Light is a 2.5D sidescrolling RPG adventure that follows the story of Aurora when she awakens in the land of Lemuria. The game is beautiful, the gameplay is simple and functional, and the story is fascinating. From the looks of things, this game is a MUST GET. For jut $14.99... there shouldn't be much of a reason why you wouldn't be able to buy Child of Light.

Wow. Just wow. This is the first review I've ever written, and I've played alot of steam games. But this one was so moving that I just had to write one.

The first thing that comes to mind is how polished the game is, good on the technical designers for making sure that the controls are intuitive and respond well. I know alot of people overlook how well the UI works in a game, but it responds so well, eliminates unnecessary clicking, and just overall isn't cumbersome.

The gameplay and story are a 10/10 for me. Story was great, and I'll leave it at that as to not spoil anything, but I like how all of the dialog consists of rhymes. Music could have been a bit more dramatic, but it was still great.

reviewText:
What an enchanting game.

It feels like a fairy tale with rpg elements. Like a well illustrated children's storybook come to life in video game form. RPG combat system is classic with a few updates. A lot of the tactical element of the game centers around altering how quickly you or your enemies can attack. If you can attack your enemy when their initiative meter gets into the red zone, you can interrupt them potentially setting them back an entire turn. And you have multiple options for affecting that timing.

While your attacks are turn based, you have a fairy companion controlled separately by the mouse who can heal you, or slow down your enemies and operates in real time.  Out of combat this same companion can interact with objects on the map that Aurora can't reach in a variety of ways allowing two people to play, one operating Aurora with the keyboard and the other controlling the fairy with the mouse

The trailers do a pretty good job of letting you know what you're in for and the beauty and grandeur of it all holds up throughout the game. Its proof that you can have a beautiful game without demanding that your video card spit out the maximum number of polygons and photorealistic textures and next gen lighting effects. As shown here, with some actual art direction, you can do so much more with so much less.

The story is a basic coming of age tale combined with a heroes journey. Young Princess Aurora seemingly dies in bed only to wake up in a strange new land. Able to see haunting visions of her own father falling ill from grief as he mourns her passing, she must explore her new world and try to find her way home while making friends and enemies along the way.

One annoying thing was the decision to write the game in rhyming couplets. I know that this was done to hold with the storybook fairy tale conceit but it started to wear thin for me rather quickly and had me wishing that they'd just speak plainly. But I am a childless 35 year old man (what are you looking at me for? Maybe I want a change of pace from the high octane AAA experience every now and then), so your mileage may vary. I've seen plenty of comments both ways from other people. I will say that if you find the dialog annoying, its usually not terribly essential to read all of it apart from getting side quests and there's not a huge amount of it anyway. The soundtrack and the art still make for a plenty beautiful experience even if the dialog doesn't work for you and the gameplay should be plenty fun for any fan of classic rpg gameplay.

But other than that, everything about this game was great. Nice change of pace too. And again speaking as a childless 35 year old man, I found that it didn't get to twee" for me

reviewText: A lovely game, overall, though it took me a while to get into it. I'm not a fan of the Final Fantasy style fights, but, eh... The game itself is simple enough, with Aurora an exiled girl running and flying around, collecting a band of warriors drawn from the various fantasy races, fighting random evil and exorcising the big baddies. The narrative is fine, and would do better were it not for the horrible doggerel it is written in. It is a problem of good narrative made bad to fit into cramped and unwieldy rhyme: it would have been better to keep a bedtime story style with prose and some couplets at the end of each scene. Dialogue appears between companions at the end of fights (by the end, that is), which was unwelcome, since by that point the various interruptions the game presents tend to add up to a nuisance.\n\nFor as bad as the rhymes were, though, the graphics were outstanding. Watching Aurora grow and transform is very well done: she is a good character design, and the animations overall (especially of her) are very good. The scenes appear to be hand-drawn, and the addition of Igniculus (the sprite/elemental) creates nice shadow/lighting effects (as well as very important strategies in the fight sequences). The graphics are really what make this game worth playing. The soundtrack, also, is very well produced (I can't confirm, but it seemed to me to be actual orchestral tracks for some of the key melodies). If you can get over the bad verse, you should find this game to be quite enjoyable. 7/10.

reviewText:
**CANNOT RECOMMEND DUE TO UPLAY REQUIREMENTS**

This game is gorgeous, and I was quite attracted to the artistic style of the game and the themes of its story.  However, the turn-based RPG combat felt trite and out of place given the rest of the game experience.  It was also disappointing that grinding through these combat encounters was frequently the only means of story progression.  The artistry of the world is no mean feat, but the game play was not particularly unique or innovative and the story lost much of its thematic power through experience grinds and interruptions announcing Uplay unlock/ achievement events.

Had I noticed this required a continuously-connected Uplay account, I simply would not have made the purchase.  I like the game, but I just don't play it because of the hassle involved.  Logging into both Steam and Uplay back to back, and being unable to access a single-player game for which I have already paid whenever the internet is wonky, is absolute rubbish.  I am disappointed that Steam is offering games with this type of DRM and promoting them with sales.

reviewText:
Excellent music and artwork. Reasonable amount of content for $15. Fairly strategic turn-based battles for a jRPG-style active combat system (deeper than simply mashing A/X to get through one tedious grind after the next).

If you're not manly enough to play a fairy tale game about a little girl, then I don't even know what to say to you bro.

P.S. Yes it requires Uplay, if you're adamant about boycotting those titles.
